commit_message:
Support to delete claimed message

When deleting a claimed message, Zaqar v2 API requires client to
specify the claim_id as query parameter. However, this is not
RESTful. So this patch tries to address this issue by rebuilding
request URI only for deleting claimed message operation rather than
supporting query parameter for all resources' deleting operation.

Change-Id: I614014373c8fb14e13ff1f00837ea36c41c3fe2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/55/388455/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # For Zaqar v2 API requires client to specify claim_id as query # parameter when deleting a message that has been claimed, we # rebuild the request URI if claim_id is not None. if self.claim_id: request.uri += '?claim_id=%s' % self.claim_id

commit_message:
networking-bgpvpn: remove check-requirements jobs

As a follow up to I21c8aadd82249882243bf8e23b37e23fcb62f507,
and after an IRC discussion with the infra team [1], there seems
to be an agreement that simply removing the check-requirements
job from networking-bgpvpn is the best *temporarily* solution,
until a decision is made on how a project like ours should work
in branches.

We plan to add automated requirements checks when it will be clear
how to do it in our different branches.

This change is dependent on Ibc3fb11598298938bc72be2ce8fc12d5e231b6bc
to guarantee that we won't propagate bogus requirements in global
requirements.

Also related: email thread starting at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/079773.html

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-infra/%23openstack-infra.2015-11-24.log.html#t2015-11-24T16:03:50

Change-Id: I60df289591a11b53de5f15835137892e32873b15
Depends-On: Ibc3fb11598298938bc72be2ce8fc12d5e231b6bc

Where possible, we should avoid having an extra migration soon after

commit_message:
Record the open question around resource audits

When using the inventory table, it is likely to grow very large.
Where possible, we should avoid having an extra migration soon after
introducing the table, due to how expensive that migration will be.

We need a way to check the IP allocations are in sync with neutron's
view of its IP capacity. This is being discussed in various specs
including the generic-resource-pools spec and the routed networks spec.

Change-Id: I97856cbc628e05abe50b09915b6e03f74b328c96
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/16/274716/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Please note, it is currently an open question how we audit the usage of IPs to make sure neutron and the scheduler are not our of sync. One suggestion is to add field into the inventory table. Due to the expected size of this table, we must ensure we have resolved this audit issue before populating that table with data. Otherwise operators will face an expensive schema migration.

commit_message:
Add generic scheduling/placement API

This blueprint/spec proposes replacing the server groups API extension
with an entirely different, simpler, and more flexible system for
infoming the Nova scheduler about placement preferences at the time
of launch, including "soft" scheduling and proximate-distance placement.

Change-Id: I9a35eb9d13123bb7f020c382f6b402e91a08de31
Blueprint: generic-scheduling-policies
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/37/183837/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Generic Scheduling Policies =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/generic-scheduling-policies This spec introduces a new API for cloud users to inform Nova about their instance placement preferences in a generic fashion, without the need for "server groups". Problem description =================== The current "server group" API extension is awkward, incomplete, and confusing to cloud users. The use case here is very simple: Alice wants to launch an instance and make sure that the instance does not land on a compute host that contains other instances of that type. The current user experience is that Alice creates a "server group" like so: nova server-group-create $GROUP_NAME --policy=anti-affinity and then, when Alice wishes to launch an instance and make sure it doesn't land on a host with another of that instance type, she does the following: nova boot --group $GROUP_UUID ... There are myriad problems with the above user experience and implementation. Let me explain them. 1. The user isn't creating a "server group" when they issue a nova server-group-create call. They are creating a *policy* and *calling it a group*. Cognitive dissonance results from this mismatch. 2. There's no way to add an existing server to this "group". What this means is that the user needs to effectively have pre-considered their environment and policy before ever launching a VM. To realize why this is a problem, consider the following: - User creates three VMs that consume high I/O utilization - User then wants to launch three more VMs of the same kind and make sure they don't end up on the same hosts as the others No can do, since the first three VMs weren't started using a --group scheduler hint. 3. There's no way to remove members from the group 4. There's no way to manually add members to the server group 5. The act of telling the scheduler to place instances near or away from some other instances has been hidden behind the server group API, which means that users doing a nova help boot will see a --group option that doesn't make much sense, as it doesn't describe the scheduling policy activity. Use Cases ---------- As a normal cloud user, when launching one or more instances, I want to tell Nova to place those instances near or not near some generic thing. I do *not* want to create some server group and maintain membership in a server group. I simply want to inform Nova that I wish to be near or not near some other thing, the degree to which I care about how strict the end placement is, and the general proximity or distance from some other thing that my instances are placed. Project Priority ----------------- This blueprint does not fall under any Nova project priorities. Proposed change =============== I propose to deprecate the server groups API extension entirely and replace it with a simpler and more generic method of indicating placement preferences. A new API microversion will introduce the following functionality that describes generic placement preferences: `POST /servers` -- The main API call to launch an instance will add a new `placement` key to the resource body:: 'placement': { ... } within the new `placement` JSON object shall be a set of optional attributes to inform the scheduler about placement preferences:: 'near_tag': <string>, 'not_near_tags': <list_of_strings>, 'absolute': <boolean>, 'distance': <unsiged_integer> The above new attributes shall have the following meaning: * `near_tag`: indicates that the scheduler should place all instances in the request spec near other instances having a tag. * `not_near_tags`: indicates that the scheduler should place all instances in the request spec *not* near instances having any of a list of tags. * `absolute`: (defaults to true) If false, indicates to the scheduler that if the scheduler cannot fulfill the preferred placement in absolute terms, that the scheduler should attempt a best-effort placement using less-rigid placement policies. This is sometimes called "soft (anti-)affinity". * `distance`: (defaults to 0) An unsigned integer that represents the relative distance that the scheduler should attempt to place the instances. Different deployments are free to interpret this value in different ways. For example, let's say a large public cloud deployer wishes to allow users to specify that their instances should be placed on different compute nodes within the same rack, or on different racks within the same row in a datacenter, or in different racks in different rows in a datacenter, or even in different data centers entirely. The deployer could advertise that the numbers 0-3 represent those increasing degrees of relative "distance" that instances would be placed from each other. How does this solve the issues highlighted above? In order, it solves the issues like so: 1. There's no need to have any "server group" object any more. Servers have a set of tags that may be used to identify a type of server. The activity of launching an instance would now have options for the user to indicate their affinity preference, which removes the cognitive dissonance that happens due to the user needing to know what a server group is (a policy, not a group). 2. Since there is no more need to maintain a separate server group object, if a user launched 3 instances and then wanted to make sure that 3 new instances don't end up on the same hosts, all the user needs to do is tag the existing instances with a tag, and issue a call to: nova boot --not-near-tag $TAG ... and the affinity policy is applied properly. 3. Removal of members of the "server group" is no longer an issue. Simply untag a server to remove it from the set of servers you wish to use in applying some affinity policy 4. Likewise, since there's no server group object, in order to relate an existing server to another is to simply place a tag on the server. 5. The act of applying affinity policies is now directly related to the act of launching instances, which is where it should be. Alternatives ------------ We could go down the path of the server group API, with its corresponding warts and cognitive dissonance. Data model impact ----------------- The following tables will be deleted entirely from the Nova database: * `instance_groups' * `instance_group_policy` * `instance_group_members` A new field `placement_preferences` will be added to the `instances` table in the Nova database. This will be a `TEXT` field containing the JSON-ified set of placement preferences that were specified at launch time for an instance. It is important to keep these placement preferences with the instance in order to re-apply those placement policies during any resize/migrate operation. REST API impact --------------- The existing `os-server-groups` API extension will be DEPRECATED. A new API microversion will change the Controller for the servers resource's `POST` command to allow the `placement` object in the request body, along with the `near_tag`, `not_near_tags`, `absolute`, and `distance` fields. The new microversion should validate incoming request body data using the following JSON-Schema document:: placement = { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'near_tag': { 'type': 'string' }, 'not_near_tags': { 'type': 'array', 'items': 'string' }, 'absolute': { 'type': 'boolean' }, 'distance': { 'type': 'integer' } }, 'anyOf': [ {'required': ['near_tag']}, {'required': ['not_near_tags']} ] } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- novaclient should add new CLI options for controlling the injection of the placement preferences in the launch instance request:: --place-near-tag <STRING> --place-not-near-tags <LIST_OF_STRINGS> [--no-place-absolute] --place-distance <INTEGER> Performance Impact ------------------ The performance of policy matching queries that the scheduler does should increase due to a simpler format that does not need to cross more than a single table (`tags`) for the non-distance-accounting proximity queries. Other deployer impact --------------------- Besides documentation that fully covers the deprecation of the old server groups API extension and the new functionality, there should not be much impact to deployers. Developer impact ---------------- The source code that handles placement decisions should be a LOT simpler and structured after these changes are introduced. Implementation ============== TODO Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jaypipes (Jay Pipes) Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ * Server tagging functionality Testing ======= Full unit and functional tests shall be included with the code, including tests of various placement scenarios involving proximity, various distances, and anti-affinity. Documentation Impact ==================== Full devref and API documentation will be provided by the patch submitter(s). References ========== Original mailing list discussion around removing the server groups API extension: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/033746.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

commit_message:
WIP: Support live migration with macvtap SR-IOV

Change-Id: I23390c3e8e453e3f494f910bc7dd69866a255e51
Implements: blueprint sriov-live-migration
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/77/136077/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support live migration with macvtap SR-IOV ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/sriov-live-migration In Juno release, SR-IOV is added into nova (Refer to [NOVA_SRIOV]_). To boot up an instance with neutron SR-IOV ports, the ports need to be first created with vnic_type being either direct or macvtap. We'll use the terms direct SR-IOV and macvtap SR-IOV, respectively, to differentiate the two vnic types in this spec. The port IDs can then be provided in the nova boot API. However, instances created with SR-IOV ports can not be live migrated in Juno. Problem description =================== SR-IOV makes it possible for a VM to directly send packets to the VIC (virtual interface card) without having the hypervisor involved. In the case of direct SR-IOV, the physical VIC driver is running in the guest VM which directly controls the hardware. Live migration requires copying of VM's state including the hardware state from the source host to the destination host. Due to the lack of visibility of the SR-IOV hardware state in the hypervisor, however, live migration with direct SR-IOV is not possible without hypervisor change or using other techniques, such as that suggested in [EDWIN_LIVE]_ and [COMPS_LIVE]_. Fortunately, libvirt supports live migration with macvtap SR-IOV. With macvtap SR-IOV, a macvtap interface residing on the host is directly connected to an ethernet interface that corresponds to a virtaul function (VF) on the VIC. the VM runs a virtual ethernet driver (e.g. virtio_net) that delivers the packets to the macvtap interface that passes them directly to the VIC. With a bit of sacrifice of the packet latency and network thoroughput, it's possible to live migrate VMs that use it. In this spec, we'll focus on the support of live migration with macvtap SR-IOV. Live migration with direct SR-IOV may be addressed in the future. Also note that VMs with direct PCI passthrough devices can't be live migrated. Use Cases ---------- * As an operator, I want to be able to live migrate my instances with macvtap SR-IOV ports Project Priority ----------------- This was mentioned in the Paris summit, and considered as one of Bugs that should be tackled in Kilo. Proposed change =============== Check If The VM Is Live Migratable ---------------------------------- Given that a VM with direct SR-IOV and/or direct PCI passthrough devices can't be live migrated, when a user enters the request to live migrate such a VM, the request will be rejected with proper reason. Live migration will only be attempted on a VM without direct SR-IOV and/or direct PCI passthrough devices. Renaming Interface to Keep Domain XML Unchanged ----------------------------------------------- To live migrate a VM with libvrit, the VM's domain XML must remain unchanged after migrating to the destination host. This implies that information that's local to the host such as the PCI device address can't be used in the domain XML. To meet this requirement, this spec proposes an interface renaming mechanism. An example of the interface XML with macvtap SR-IOV in a domain XML:: <interface type='direct'> <mac address='fa:16:3e:ae:7f:c5'/> <source dev='eth20' mode='passthrough'/> <model type='virtio'/> <driver name='vhost'/> <alias name='net0'/> <address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x03' function='0x0'/> </interface> Note that in the source dev clause above, eth20 is local to the compute node where the domain is hosted. The interface with the same name eth20 on the destination host may have been used or may not be used for this VM. Therefore, a location independent naming convention for interface names is needed. Fortunately, we can use the neutron port ID to rename the interface before generating the domain XML. With renaming, when the VM is initially launched, the interface XML in the VM's domain XML will look like:: <interface type='direct'> <mac address='fa:16:3e:ae:7f:c5'/> <source dev='srv<12 chars from neutron-port-id>' mode='passthrough'/> <model type='virtio'/> <driver name='vhost'/> <alias name='net0'/> <address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x03' function='0x0'/> </interface> The maximum length of an interface name is 15 characters. There is a corner case that runs like this: * A VM with macvtap SR-IOV port on Host-1 is migrated to Host-2 * Later, it is migrated back to Host-1 If it happens that during the second migration, a different port on Host-1 than the one the VM originally used is allocated for the VM, then this port would be renamed with the same name as the original port if the original port were still free after the first migration. The possible name collision can be resolved by renaming the original port to srv<domain>-<bus>-<slot>-<func> after the first migration has been completed. For example, if eth20 has the PCI address as 0000:0a:01.1, it will be renamed as srv0000-0a-01-1 after migration is completed. Device/VIF Compatibility ------------------------ In a multi-vendor cloud environment, SR-IOV capable NIC adaptors may come from different vendors. Some adaptors support fabric extender (such as Cisco's VMFEX), others support hardware virtual ethernet bridge (such as Intel and Mellanox). Nova currently supports two VIF types for SR-IOV: VIF_TYPE_802_QBH and VIF_TYPE_HW_VEB. Each type has its own interface XML. With macvtap, the same virtio driver is used in the VM regardless of the VIF types. However, to be live migratable, the domain XML must remain the same. This means, the PCI devices on the destination host must be compatible in terms of VIF types. It's possible to migrate from a host with intel SR-IOV adpators to another with Mellanox's, or vice-versa. Currently, however, it's not possible to select the destination host based on compatible VIF types. It is possible, though, to relieve this restriction if all the SR-IOV adaptors in a cloud are VIF compatible. A nova boolean config option *sriov-vif-compatible* will be provided for this purpose. If *sriov-vif-compatible* is false, live migration is only possible with the same type of SR-IOV capable NIC adaptors. In the future, with enhancement in the nova scheduler, the restriction may be relieved. PCI Requests, Scheduling and SR-IOV Device Allocation ----------------------------------------------------- For live migration, the original PCI requests associated with the instance cannot be used as is to schedule the destination host and allocate SR-IOV devices on it with two reasons: * they don't contain information To ensure device compatibility * they don't contain information to correlate a request with a neutron port New PCI requests will be created with the flag *is_new* to be true. To ensure device compatiblity, and if *sriov-vif-compatible* is false, the original PCI requests are added with two new attributes if they are not present in the requests: vendor_id and product_id, which can be obtained from the neutron ports or PCI devices allocated for the original requests. The original PCI request ID can be used to correlate the allocated PCI device with its requested network. Refer to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/86606/ for how a PCI request id is initialy created. To correlate a PCI request and the allocated SR-IOV device to a neutron port, however, the original PCI request ID needs to be modified. The neutron port ID can be used as the new PCI request ID, and update to the PCI request with the new PCI request ID can be made while updating the neutron port with the PCI device information. To schedule the destination host, the newly-created PCI requests will be added into the filter properties right before the call to select_destinations. The newly-created PCI requests are also used to allocate SR-IOV devices in the pre_live_migration phase on the destination host. The management and use of the old, new, current PCI requests are similar to the instance type management during migration. Basically, * the new requests are used for device allocation on the destination host. * the old requests are used for rollback. * after successful migration, the new is copied to become the current, and both the new and the old are deleted. If migration to the destination host fails, SR-IOV devices allocated for the instance must be freed. Note that for migration (live or cold or resize), PCI devices are allocated on both the original host and the destination host at the same time. The instance object is associated with a list of PCI devices allocated for it. The access method to retrieve the PCI devices for an instance doesn't use host ID as filter. There may be changes needed to make sure that on a particular host, PCI devices associated with an instance are actually located on the host itself. migrate_instance_finish ----------------------- This method in the neutronv2 API module is invoked for instance resize, cold and live migration. In this method, neutron ports associated with the instance will be updated with the new binding information. This method will be enhanced so that PCI information is updated for SR-IOV ports as well. Note that as a result of updating the binding information which includes the new PCI information, operations on the hardware or remote devices may be taking place. Success of those operations are not guaranteed. This is an existing limitation in the current workflow to support migration, and is out of the scope of this specification. Alternatives ------------ There are two other alternative solutions that were discussed among the communities. The first one involves creating a network XML per neutron SR-IOV port. The second one involves creating a network XML per physical network. The first alternative is similar to the interface renaming approach as described in the **proposed section**. For each neutron SR-IOV port, a netwrok XML is created and referenced in the domain XML when the instance is initially launchedn. During migration, a network XML with the same name needs to be created on the destination host during the pre_live_migration phase. Currently in the pci_passthrough_whitelist, each SR-IOV pci device is tagged with the physical network name which the device is connected to. In the second alternative solution, a network XML per physical network can be created during the PCI device initialization time. Each network XML contains all the SR-IOV PCI devices that belongs to the physical network. The domain XML will only need to refer to this network XML when defining SR-IOV interfaces that are on that network. Therefore, the requirement for unchanged domain XML is guaranteed. There is a problem with this solution, though. By doing so, allocation of individual PCI device is managed by libvirt, and there doesn't seem to be a libvirt API that can be invoked to get knowledge of the PCI device allocated for each port before the instance is launched. However, such knowledge is critical in properly configuring the device. Both alternatives require management of libvirt network XML, which currently is not supported by Nova. Data model impact ----------------- N/A REST API impact --------------- N/A Security impact --------------- N/A Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers need to be aware of the limitations imposed with live migration in an SR-IOV capable cloud: * live migration is only possible with macvtap SR-IOV with a bit of sacrifice of thouroughput compared with direct SR-IOV * live migration may only be performed with VIF-compatible SR-IOV capable adaptors. Developer impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <baoli> Work Items ---------- * Check live migratability * PCI requests management * interface renaming * SR-IOV device allocation * migrate_instance_finish Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD References ========== .. [NOVA_SRIOV] `enable a nova instance to be booted up with neutron SRIOV ports <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/pci-passthrough-sriov>`_ .. [EDWIN_LIVE] `Live Migration with Pass-through Device for Linux VM <http://shikee.net/read/VM_OLS08.pdf>`_ .. [COMPS_LIVE] `CompSC: Live Migration with Pass-through Devices <http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/srg/netos/vee_2012/papers/p109.pdf>`_

commit_message:
Fix method signature vif invocation

The vif rollback method used the wrong signature.  This fixes it.

Change-Id: I14a5298c74d71a91f218a0e1af676ec2af3359ba
Closes-Bug: #1636795

commit_message:
Fix method signature vif invocation

The vif rollback method used the wrong signature.  This fixes it.

Change-Id: I14a5298c74d71a91f218a0e1af676ec2af3359ba
Closes-Bug: #1636795

commit_message:
alembic: db migration fails

the patch of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/390017/ caused the
following exception during db migration.
This patch reverts the migration scripts change of the patch.

commit_message:
libvirt: Separate functions to get root, ephemeral, and swap

Move the creation of the root disk, ephemeral disks, and the swap disk
from _create_image into separate functions. This directly makes
_create_image more readable, but the primary purpose is to support
subsequent change Ia085e218, which iterates over disks in
finish_migration without creating them.

We refactor the test_create_image_* tests which exclusively tested
epehemeral disk creation to instead test _get_ephemeral_disks, and add
some additional tests for ephemeral disks created from block device
mappings.

Change-Id: If2fcc97928607189446e067886f70786bcc1cb3f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/333984/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_swap_disk(self, context, instance, disk_mapping, block_device_info, fallback=None): if 'disk.swap' not in disk_mapping: return flavor = instance.get_flavor() mapping = disk_mapping['disk.swap'] swap_mb = 0 swap = driver.block_device_info_get_swap(block_device_info) if driver.swap_is_usable(swap): swap_mb = swap['swap_size'] elif (flavor.swap > 0 and not block_device.volume_in_mapping(mapping['dev'], block_device_info)): swap_mb = flavor.swap if swap_mb > 0: size = swap_mb * units.Mi fn = functools.partial(self._create_swap, swap_mb=swap_mb) return self.image_backend.from_func( instance, 'disk.swap', context, fn, "swap_%s" % swap_mb, size, fallback=fallback) return None swap_disk = self._get_swap_disk(context, instance, disk_mapping, block_device_info, fallback=fallback_from_host) if swap_disk is not None: swap_disk.create()
deleted_lines: def from_func(name, func, cache_name, size, image_type=None): return self.image_backend.from_func( instance, name + suffix, context, func, cache_name, size, fallback=fallback_from_host, image_type=image_type) inst_type = instance.get_flavor() if 'disk.swap' in disk_mapping: mapping = disk_mapping['disk.swap'] swap_mb = 0 swap = driver.block_device_info_get_swap(block_device_info) if driver.swap_is_usable(swap): swap_mb = swap['swap_size'] elif (inst_type['swap'] > 0 and not block_device.volume_in_mapping( mapping['dev'], block_device_info)): swap_mb = inst_type['swap'] if swap_mb > 0: size = swap_mb * units.Mi fn = functools.partial(self._create_swap, swap_mb=swap_mb) from_func('disk.swap', fn, "swap_%s" % swap_mb, size).create()

subject: libvirt: Add DiskFromImage and DiskFromFunc
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-23 18:00:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/08d3e1af210414a610929e5df2149db075435267', 'message': "Add Backend from_image and from_func

This change adds an interface to backend which allows us to specify
how a disk would be created, but defer the actual creation. This
allows us to make 2 subsequent changes:

* Implement a generic method to iterate over disks, and allow the
  caller to determine whether they should be created or not. This will
  allow us to resize and check, but not create, in finish_migration
  whilst still re-using the disk iteration logic currently in
  _create_image.

* Provide a hook point for the addition of instance metadata prior to
  calling the backend.

We don't address callers in _create_images_and_backing yet, but these
will be addressed.

Note that changes to tests are minimal, meaning we continue to
validate that the code is calling down to cache() as before.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-instance-storage

Change-Id: I099a0b372ef4801bd8a81561dc9d69a472bc2d91
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-24 08:39:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7149342ccf83f303fc701556059522a5b80ddc04', 'message': "Add Backend from_image and from_func

commit_message:
libvirt: Add DiskFromImage and DiskFromFunc

This change adds an interface to backend which allows us to specify
how a disk is created, but defer the actual creation. This allows us
to implement a generic method to iterate over disks, and allow the
caller to determine whether they should be created or not. This allows
us to resize and check, but not create, in finish_migration whilst
still re-using the disk iteration logic currently in _create_image.

We don't address callers in _create_images_and_backing yet, but these
will be addressed.

Note that changes to tests are deliberately minimal, so that we
continue to validate the code is calling down to cache() as before.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-instance-storage

Change-Id: I099a0b372ef4801bd8a81561dc9d69a472bc2d91

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, instance=None, disk_name=None, path=None): super(FakeImage, self).__init__(path, 'file', 'fake')

commit_message:
libvirt: Add _create_external_boot_disks

This replaces the manual creation of external boot disks in
_create_image, as well as calls to _fetch_instance_kernel_ramdisk. The
latter function is removed, as well as _try_fetch_image because
_fetch_instance_kernel_ramdisk was its last caller.

As seen in test changes, this introduces a minor change in behaviour.
Previously, _fetch_instance_kernel_ramdisk would download directly to
the instance directory. We now use the image cache, as for all other
image downloads.

Change-Id: If460496f4466acc1a019f571b2245de07413ca2a

deleted_lines: self.mox.StubOutWithMock(drvr, '_fetch_instance_kernel_ramdisk') drvr._fetch_instance_kernel_ramdisk(self.context, instance, fallback_from_host=None) mock.call(context=self.context, target=kernel_path, mock.call(context=self.context, target=ramdisk_path,

commit_message:
virt: add method get_serial_console to ironic driver

Adds get_serial_console that returns a typed object with
all necessary information to connect to the ironic instance

Change-Id: I19c799946860297f03cb62dbb64ebd46047854e8
Partial-Implements: blueprint shellinabox-http-proxy
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/99/302499/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six.moves.urllib.parse as urlparsefrom nova.console import type as ctype def get_serial_console(self, context, instance): """Aquire serial console information. :param context: request context :param instance: nova.objects.instance.Instance to acquire its serial console connection :returns: ConsoleSerial object """ node = self._validate_instance_and_node(instance) try: self.ironicclient.call("node.set_console_mode", node.uuid, True) console = self.ironicclient.call("node.get_console", node.uuid) except (exception.NovaException, ironic.exc.InternalServerError, ironic.exc.BadRequest) as e: msg = (_LE("Failed to request Ironic to aquire serial console " "%(inst)s: %(reason)s") % {'inst': instance.uuid, 'reason': six.text_type(e)}) LOG.warning(msg) raise exception.ConsoleTypeUnavailable(console_type='shellinabox') console_info = console["console_info"] if console_info is None: LOG.warning(_LE('The instance console is not enabled.'), instance=instance) raise exception.ConsoleTypeUnavailable(console_type='shellinabox') if console_info["type"] != "shellinabox": LOG.warning(_LE('Only supports "shellinabox" console type.'), instance=instance) raise exception.ConsoleTypeUnavailable(console_type='shellinabox') try: url = urlparse.urlparse(console_info.get("url"), "") except AttributeError: LOG.warning(_LE('console url is invalid.'), instance=instance) raise exception.ConsoleTypeUnavailable(console_type='shellinabox') if url.scheme not in ["http", "https"]: LOG.warning(_LE('only "http" and "https" are supported.'), instance=instance) raise exception.ConsoleTypeUnavailable(console_type='shellinabox') return ctype.ConsoleSerial(host=url.hostname, port=url.port)

commit_message:
libvirt: Rename _cleanup_resize to confirm_migration

There are no additional callers of _cleanup_resize or additional logic
within confirm_migration so collapse both into one method.

Change-Id: Ie16ce1a83c22173a24f5e8436ca1d99f99a65015

commit_message:
Configurable guest's NIC PCI address

A user can specify to launch a guest with multiple virtual NICs but in the
guest it's not trivial to correlate the NICs requested with the actual PCI
network devices created.  This blueprint addresses this limitation by enabling
the user to specify the PCI address of the virtual NICs to correlate them back
to the guest.

Change-Id: I298e1fb6f096e6256f34253953f41d42e8c6679d
Implements: blueprint config-guest-nic-pci-address
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/86/304586/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Configurable guest's NIC PCI address ==================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/config-guest-nic-pci-address A user can specify to launch a guest with multiple virtual NICs but in the guest it's not trivial to correlate the NICs requested with the actual PCI network devices created. This blueprint addresses this limitation by enabling the user to specify the PCI address of the virtual NICs to correlate them back to the guest. Problem description =================== It's currently possible for a user to launch a guest with multiple virtual network interfaces. Minimally, each virtual NIC is specified with the network ID on which they should be attached along with other optional parameters (port name, IPv4/IPv6 address, etc.). However in the guest it's not trivial for the user to correlate the virtual NICs requested to the actual PCI devices/interfaces created. If the user lists the interfaces in the guest (using ifconfig for e.g.), all the interfaces will be enumerated (for e.g., eth0, eth1, etc.) but we need to map the interfaces to the requested networks. It is important to note that the virtual NICs won't necessarily be created in the guest following the order specified on the command line or with horizon. A user might want to configure an interface differently depending on which network a given virtual NIC is attached to (for e.g., enabling DHCP, specify MTU, etc.) for any initial boot strapping of the guest's network connectivity. Also a user might use pre-canned images for its guests that require the networking devices to use specific PCI addresses. The current behaviour with openstack would provide those devices with quasi-random PCI addresses which impacts the portability of those applications. This feature is important for NFV type of applications. Nova currently doesn't have the ability to assign the PCI addresses of the virtual NIC devices. If not specified, libvirt is responsible to allocate and assign PCI addresses for the devices of a guest (see [0]). It's also possible with libvirt to use the same XML interface to specify the PCI addresses. The target PCI address can found in the libvirt XML description of the instance. For example: :: <interface type='bridge'> <mac address='fa:16:3e:b0:c1:bc'/> <source bridge='br-int'/> <virtualport type='openvswitch'> <parameters interfaceid='9b0d84ed-d564-47c5-8cc2-067033928fb5'/> </virtualport> <target dev='tap9b0d84ed-d5'/> <model type='virtio'/> <address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x03' function='0x0'/> </interface> Use Cases --------- A user launch a guest and specify to attach it to two different networks and wants to specify the guest's NIC PCI addresses: The user can then log in the guest and configure the interfaces knowing which interface correspond to which NIC request. Proposed change =============== This solution propose to extend the compute REST API in order to accept a new parameter that will be used the specify the virtual PCI address for a given network port requested when launching an instance. The suggestion is to use "vif_pci_address" for the new parameter in the nova.api.openstack.compute.ServersController object. The NIC PCI address format is: :: <domain>:<bus>:<slot>.<function> The REST API also needs to validate the value of the PCI address fields following the PCI specification. Each hypervisors can also have limitations for the range of PCI addresses that can be specified by a user. Some PCI addresses might be reserved to internal use by an hypervisor. It's preferable to detect possible errors as soon as possible. The python-novaclient would also be modified in order to use this feature. For example: :: $ nova boot --image=guest.img --flavor=small \ --nic net-id=$NET1ID,vif-pci-address=0000:00:07.0 \ --nic net-id=$NET2ID,vif-pci-address=0000:00:08.0 guest0 The value of the PCI address will be store in a new string field in the nova.objects.NetworkRequest object which will be used when booting the instance. The PCI addresses need to be persisted so that when an instance is re-created (for e.g. after a migration), the correct value is used. Note that the original list of requested networks is not persisted. The proposition is to persist the PCI address in the InstanceInfoCache.NetworkModel object. See network-requested-vif-model.rst for more detailed explanation on how this would work. The guest's NIC PCI address will be exported in the libvirt XML definition of the instance when the instance is spawned (in the _get_guest_config() method). Libvirt already support this feature but the Nova libvirt driver needs to be modified to specify it in the XML. Note that it is proposed to only implement this feature for libvirt. Other hypervisor could be later on modified using this framework. For this purpose the nova libvirt driver will be modified as follow: * Modify nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtConfigGuestInterface to store the NIC PCI address and add support for parsing and outputting the XML object with this new attribute. * The nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtDriver will now have to handle the guest NIC PCI address when outputting the instance XML. The PCI address will be extracted from the NetworkModel and set in the LibvirtConfigGuestInterface object. The scope of this feature is limited to network devices for the moment. It could be extended to support other type of devices (disk, etc.). It's quite possible that not all hypervisors can support this feature. For an heterogeneous cloud that supports multiple different type of hypervisor in the same domain, extra care has to be taken in order to schedule guests that wants to specify the PCI addresses for it's network attachment. For this reason we propose to extend the host capabilities to report wether or not they support this feature. A new scheduler filter would be implemented for filtering out compute nodes that can't support it. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The following changes are expected for the nova compute REST API: * The /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers GET method needs to return the NIC PCI addresses for an instance. * The /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers POST method needs to support the new vif_pci_address argument. The proposed change necessitate to add a new microversion to the REST API. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Changes in python-novaclient are required. We propose to only support configuring the NIC PCI address through the command line interface for now. But it's also possible to extend horizon as such. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- This solution is documented for libvirt only. Other hypervisors that also support the specification of the guest's NIC PCI address would require similar changes. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ludovic.beliveau (ludovic.beliveau@windriver.com) Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add new vif_pci_address in the compute REST API. * Modify the nova.objects.NetworkRequest object. * Modify the nova.network.model.VIF object to allow persistency of the new requested_network field. * Modify libvirt driver to handle the vif_pci_address now included in the NetworkRequest object. * Extend host capabilities. * Implement new filter. * Parse new argument in python-novaclient. Dependencies ============ The python-novaclient will need to be modified to accept the command line argument for specifying the guest virtual PCI address for the virtual NICs. Testing ======= As usual, tox unit tests will have to be written to properly test this new feature. This feature can be tested in a virtual environment and therefore does not require any specialized hardware. Documentation Impact ==================== Since Nova REST API is impacted, the corresponding documentation is require to change (http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html). The Nova command line documentation also require changes (http://docs.openstack.org/cli-reference/nova.html). References ========== [0] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsAddress [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/304582 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced but no changes merged. * - Newton - Re-proposed.

commit_message:
Support "locked" filter when list servers

After the implementation of
bp/add-locking-information-in-server-get-response

we now have locked information in the response data
of show method, but it is not good enough. As we may
have a large number of locked instances, it will take
forever to check the instances one by one, it will be
really useful if we can list all the locked instances
in one call.

This spec propose to add support for 'locked' filter for
List API.

APIImpact: "locked" filter will be added for "list" method

Change-Id: Ie970e7974ee268ab2366ebcc8cf0d4111dabc375
Blueprint: support-list-locked-instances
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/49/292749/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= Support "locked" filter when list servers ========================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-list-locked-instances Add support of ``locked`` filter when list servers. Users can use this filter to display only all instances that are ``locked``. Problem description =================== After the implementation of blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-locking-information-in-server-get-response we can now get the locked information in the response data of show method, but it is not good enough. As we may have a large number of locked instances, it will take forever to check the instances one by one, it will be really useful if we can list all the locked instances in one call. Use Cases --------- As in large scale deployment, a large number of instances may be locked due to various reasons, we have to unlock them before perform other options, it will take forever to check one by one to find out all the locked instances. As an admin, if I can list all locked instances in one call, life will be much easier. Proposed change =============== Add a new microversion to support for ``locked`` filter when calling ``List`` API. Alternatives ------------ Don't support ``locked`` filter and check all the instances one by one with ``show`` API to find out all ``locked`` instances. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- * URL: * /v2.1/servers/detail?locked=true: * Request method: * GET Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zhenyu Zheng Work Items ---------- 1. Add microversion to GET /servers/detail?locked=True to support ``locked`` filter; 2. Add nova-client support for list with ``locked`` filter; 2. Add related tests. Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Related tests will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== References ========== History =======

commit_message:
Link to os-security-groups in server-create response

The Nova API always adds the 'default' security group to a server POST
response even if the Neutron network that the instance is using has port
security disabled. This is misleading. A better approach is to provide a
link to the os-security-groups API in the server POST response so the user
can get the security groups for the server after it's created.

APIImpact

Spec for blueprint server-create-secgroups-response-link

Change-Id: Ie321d1d8bbc81fb4bebd81d44464036ec5396451
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/72/301372/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Link to os-security-groups in server-create response ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/server-create-secgroups-response-link The Nova API always adds the 'default' security group to a server POST response even if the Neutron network that the instance is using has port security disabled. This is misleading. A better approach is to provide a link to the os-security-groups API in the server POST response so the user can get the security groups for the server after it's created. Problem description =================== The Nova API adds the 'default' security group to a server-create request even if the user didn't request that security group. This is problematic when using Neutron as the network service and the network that we are using has port_security_enabled=False. Part of that problem is `fixed in bug 1175464`_. One issue with the fix is it doesn't address that we return a list of security groups with the server create response. `[1]`_ When using Neutron, we don't know what security groups are going to be applied to an instance (port/network) from the Nova API, and defaulting to 'default' in the response when no specific security groups are requested can be wrong. Use Cases --------- As a cloud user, I want to get an accurate list of security groups applied to my server instance once it's created. Proposed change =============== This blueprint is meant to change the server POST response to replace the security_groups list in the response body with a bookmark link to the os-security-groups API which has the accurate details on security groups for the server instance. Note that this is intended for both nova-network and Neutron use cases so that we have a consistent response regardless of which network service is used in the cloud deployment. For example, this is a server POST from a Tempest run in a Neutron job: :: 2016-04-01 18:32:16.136 27388 INFO tempest.lib.common.rest_client \ [req-52aa5c0e-5cf6-4154-a075-9eaf5515fbd6 ] Request \ (AggregatesAdminTestJSON:test_aggregate_add_host_create_server_with_az): \ 202 POST http://127.0.0.1:8774/v2.1/f3203f02b9ec4c2faf6d0fd77a2f78bf/servers 2016-04-01 18:32:16.136 27388 DEBUG tempest.lib.common.rest_client \ [req-52aa5c0e-5cf6-4154-a075-9eaf5515fbd6 ] Request - Headers: {'X-Auth-Token': '<omitted>', 'Accept': 'application/json', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'} Body: {"server": { "name": "tempest-test_server-1787535030", "imageRef": "defe9732-8ea6-483a-b439-dcbb0c4682cd", "availability_zone": "tempest-test_az-1109470789", "flavorRef": "42"}} Response - Headers: {'x-openstack-nova-api-version': '2.1', 'date': 'Fri, 01 Apr 2016 18:32:16 GMT', 'content-length': '436', 'x-compute-request-id': \ 'req-52aa5c0e-5cf6-4154-a075-9eaf5515fbd6', 'status': '202', 'content-type': 'application/json', 'vary': 'X-OpenStack-Nova-API-Version', 'connection': 'close', 'location': 'http://127.0.0.1:8774/v2.1/\ f3203f02b9ec4c2faf6d0fd77a2f78bf/servers/\ 762c6a19-2097-4910-9af6-4ec8b19d0b6d'} Body: {"server": { "security_groups": [{"name": "default"}], "OS-DCF:diskConfig": "MANUAL", "id": "762c6a19-2097-4910-9af6-4ec8b19d0b6d", "links": [{ "href": "http://127.0.0.1:8774/v2.1/\ f3203f02b9ec4c2faf6d0fd77a2f78bf/servers/\ 762c6a19-2097-4910-9af6-4ec8b19d0b6d", "rel": "self"}, { "href": "http://127.0.0.1:8774/\ f3203f02b9ec4c2faf6d0fd77a2f78bf/servers/\ 762c6a19-2097-4910-9af6-4ec8b19d0b6d", "rel": "bookmark"}], "adminPass": "5osjMWVeUokF"}} The response body contains: :: "security_groups": [{"name": "default"}] That will be changed to something like: :: "security_groups": [{ "href": "http://127.0.0.1:8774/f3203f02b9ec4c2faf6d0fd77a2f78bf/\ servers/762c6a19-2097-4910-9af6-4ec8b19d0b6d/os-security-groups", "rel": "bookmark"}] More details and discussion are in the openstack-dev `mailing list thread`_. Alternatives ------------ We could add a method to the network API in Nova which, given a request, could attempt to build the list of networks that would be used for the instance and then check those for port security details and return that to the user. The problem with this is it adds much more complexity to the REST API flow and would duplicate a lot of the logic in nova.network.neutronv2.api.API.allocate_for_instance, including additional calls to the Neutron API, which we want to avoid during a server create before we cast off to the compute service to build the server. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- A microversion will be added and checked when building the security_groups response into the server-create POST output body. There are no changes to the server POST request so no API schema changes within Nova are required. As noted in the `Proposed change`_ section, when requesting a server create with the new microversion, the server response body will contain something like: :: "security_groups": [{ "href": "http://127.0.0.1:8774/f3203f02b9ec4c2faf6d0fd77a2f78bf/\ servers/762c6a19-2097-4910-9af6-4ec8b19d0b6d/os-security-groups", "rel": "bookmark"}] Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- As part of the `nova boot` command in python-novaclient, it takes the server response body and formats it into table output, including listing the security group names. As part of the microversion change for this, the python-novaclient shell would have to handle security_groups being a link rather than a list of security group dicts. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mriedem Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add a microversion and check that in SecurityGroupsOutputController._extend_servers for a server POST. If the request has the minimum microversion for this change, then return the link for the os-security-groups API in the server response body. If the microversion isn't satisfied, then return the list of dicts of security group names as it does today. * python-novaclient changes to handle the new microversion. * Tempest test changes to request a server create with the new microversion and validate the response body format. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and functional tests in Nova and an integration test in Tempest that validates the changed response when requesting with the proper microversion. Documentation Impact ==================== The Nova v2.1 REST API documentation will need to be updated. References ========== .. _fixed in bug 1175464: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/284095/ .. _mailing list thread: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-April/091162.html .. _[1]: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f8a01ccdffc13403df77148867ef3821100b5edb/nova/api/openstack/compute/security_groups.py#L475 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Virt image properties boot time override via flavor

This utilizes the Nova flavor extra-specs so that it is possible to
override any image metadata properties at instance creation time.
This avoids the need to upload the same image to glance multiple
times in order to set slightly different properties for some use cases.

Blueprint: virt-image-props-boot-override-via-flavor
Change-Id: I37b22e9235fbda55957a7a2eda7980bc7996c71f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/48/246548/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Virt image properties boot time override via flavor =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/virt-image-props-boot-override-via-flavor This utilizes the Nova flavor extra-specs so that it is possible to override any image metadata properties at instance creation time. This avoids the need to upload the same image to glance multiple times in order to set slightly different properties for some use cases. Problem description =================== Nova has the ability to use various metadata properties recorded against images in glance, to tailor the way an instance is configured at boot time. For example, it might customize the type of hardware devices exposed, or set a specific NUMA topology, or specify kernel command line arguments, or hypervisor type to deploy an instance. This works pretty well in general, but there are a significant number of scenarios where the same image may need to be booted with a variety of different properties set. Currently the only way to deal with this is to upload the same image to glance multiple times, setting different properties against each upload. This does not scale at all well, particularly if the properties need to be different for every single instance booted. Use Cases ---------- * A tenant user who uses multiple hypervisor cloud environment will be able to choose specific hypervisor for new instance via flavor. Using flavor is intuitive for users and also this does not consume any storage. * Hypervisor non-specific image type can be shared beteen multiple hypervisors and then this can reduce total usage of storage to store glance images. Proposed change =============== This proposal utilizes existing Nova flavor extra-specs field to override image metadata properties provided via Glance image. In the Nova compute manager, the metadata properties from the image will be augmented / overriden with the properties provided via flavor extra-specs. This merged set of properties will be recorded as the image system metadata for the instance. In this way no changes will be required to downstream code in the virt drivers. The virt drivers will automatically see the per-instance customized set. Also if additional image properties provided via the boot API using new `--image-prop-override` argument[1], this will override both current image properties provided via glance image property and Nova flavor extra-specs. :: $ nova flavor-show m1.small +----------------------------+-----------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +----------------------------+-----------------------------------------+ | OS-FLV-DISABLED:disabled | False | | OS-FLV-EXT-DATA:ephemeral | 0 | | disk | 20 | | extra_specs | {"hypervisor_type": "qemu", | | | "hw_numa_nodes": "2", | | | "hw_os_command_line": "console=ttyS0"} | | .... | ... | +----------------------------+-----------------------------------------+ Alternatives ------------ Use current glance metadata implementation as is. Data model impact ----------------- None The compute manager gains image metadata properties from flavor extra-specs and merge them into the existing image metadata dict which is stored in the system metadata table. As such no new storage is required. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- Glance has a facility to set image property protection, to prevent a tenant user from setting specific properties on an image. Since the image property overrides are completely done in Nova, this is invisible to glance's access control rules. To deal with this there will be a nova.conf property provided that whitelists/blacklists what properties can be overridden at instance boot time. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- When an adminsitrator sets up property protections in glance, they need to also consider whether the nova.conf property override whitelist needs to be updated too. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mtanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com> Other contributors: none Work Items ---------- * Extend the Nova compute manager to merge the boot time overrides with the image metadata properties via flavor extra-specs, storing the result in the system metadata. Dependencies ============ It depends in the compute manager being converted to use the ImageMetaProps object, which is being completed in https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:virtimageprops-19,n,z Also this SPEC depends on the original proposal of `Virt image properties boot time override`. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/230382/ Testing ======= New tempest test will be needed to boot a guest with image meta property overrides and verify that the guest configuration was correspondingly changed. Documentation Impact ==================== The usage of overriding image metadata properties usgin flavor extra-specs will need to be documented. References ========== [1] Virt image properties boot time override https://review.openstack.org/#/c/230382/

commit_message:
Add Instance Live Resize Functionality for Libvirt

This proposal aims to implement a live resize functionality for nova Libvirt
driver in order to dynamically change the flavor of an instance without
shutting it down.

blueprint live-resize-libvirt-instances

Change-Id: Ieb7c34d5c7253aeb0e386dd221b24e6164598454
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/24/303324/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================= Add Instance Live Resize Functionality for Libvirt Driver ========================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-resize-libvirt-instances There are cases when changing the resources allocated for an instance is beneficial whereas doing so with a reboot may not be suitable for the user's workflow. Currently nova does not allow such an action, making a reboot necessary for changing the flavor of an instance. This proposal aims to implement a live resize functionality for nova Libvirt driver in order to dynamically change the flavor of an instance without shutting it down. Problem description =================== Currently, in order to change resources allocated to an instance, the instance has to be shutdown. While this may be adequate for cases where the user is not content with the instance's resources, it is not helpful for cases where the user wants to change resources without shutting the server down. Use Cases --------- * A user wants to resize servers to flavors with higher resources when they come under unexpected stress. * A user realizes that their servers are mostly idle so resizes them to flavors with lower resources. * The user wants to avoid a reboot at all costs but still desires the benefit of having the ability change flavors. Proposed change =============== * Add a new API "live-resize" to be available for instance owners and project admins. * On Libvirt the allowed number of maximum vCPUs and the memory amount need to be specified. In order for the live-resize functionality to work, these values need to be set to allow the desired increase in VCPU and memory. Therefore, these values will be set to the maximum available in the physical host. * Even though this proposal aims to implement live-resize functionality for the Libvirt driver, as of QEMU 2.5.x, the most prominent virtualization type selection for Libvirt driver, a hot-unplug functionality for vCPUs on x86-64 is not available. Therefore, live-resizing a server to a flavor which has a lower amount of vCPUs is not going to work properly. The implementation is going to take this fact into account and return a descriptive error response in such a case. * The live-resize operation will be performed according to the resource specifications of a given flavor, namely the memory and VCPU count of an instance will be changed to match the given flavor. Any other resource defined in a flavor will be exempt from any dynamic change and will stay unaltered until a reboot. * An instance can be live-resized multiple times, as long as the given flavor's vCPU and memory values can be supported by the host. A similar functionality was proposed and later abandoned, albeit with some differences. In that proposal (see References), a host attempts to live-migrate the instance to another host if it does not have enough resources for live-resize. In this proposal no such implicit step is proposed, when it is determined that the host will not be able to sustain a live resize an error message will be returned. Alternatives ------------ Do not offer a way to dynamically change a server's resources. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- New compute API for live-resize action Request:: POST /v2.1/servers/{server_id}/action { "live-resize": { "flavorRef": 2 } } Response:: 200 OK On successful live-resize the response is a "200 OK" without a body. The response is not a "202 Accepted" since this operation is supposed complete in a short amount of time, whether it is successful or not. Possible error situations: * Missing or wrong keys in request - "400 Bad Request" * The instance is already in the given flavor - "409 Conflict" * The virt driver does not implement live-resize functionality - "501 Not Implemented" * The host does not have enough resources to perform the live-resize - "503 Service Unavailable" Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None, use the same notifications as cold resize. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- Users will be able to deploy a smaller number of instances because new servers will allocate a higher number of memory and vCPU after this functionality is implemented. Developer impact ---------------- The nova virt driver needs to have two additional method for dynamically changing vCPU count and memory amount of a server. Implementation for this functionality will be provided for Libvirt driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: Fahri Cihan Demirci <cihand@skyatlas.com> Other contributors: Ege Hanolu <egeh@skyatlas.com> Work Items ---------- Since this blueprint has been prepared after the implementation was completed, the following items describe existing realised work items. * Add necessary controller actions and methods for nova-api * Add neccessary RPC and manager methods for nova-conductor * Add methods for live resizing vCPU and RAM for Libvirt driver Dependencies ============ A live-resize functionality needs to be added to python-novaclient after this functionality is implemented. The already implemented novaclient command looks like the following: :: nova live-resize <instance-id-or-name> <flavor-id-or-name> Testing ======= New unit tests are going to be added for api, conductor, virt and driver implementations. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation is needed for new live-resize API usage. References ========== * Abandoned blueprint for a similar functionality: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/hot-resize * Review for abandoned blueprint: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/95054/ * A similar Cloudstack feature (for XenServer and VMware): https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/CLOUDSTACK/Dynamic+scaling+of+CPU+and+RAM History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-14 22:55:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/0352494b1c29037f7977b6ee120cb4a8f7933e5f', 'message': 'Add new filter based on thresholds of metrics

Operators want to avoid scheduling more VMs on a host(HV), when the CPU
usage on the HV is hot. A combination of metric weight and metrics-based
filter, gives a nice way to order the HVs, while scheduling. But, it
does not give a choice to exclude a HV, based on the usage. So, at
present, operators resort to disable a host from scheduling to avoid

commit_message:
Add new filter based on thresholds of metrics

Operators want to avoid scheduling more VMs on a host(HV), when the CPU
usage on the HV is hot. A combination of metric weight and metrics-based
filter, gives a nice way to order the HVs, while scheduling. But, it
does not give a choice to exclude a HV, based on the usage. So, at
present, operators resort to disable a host from scheduling to avoid
further degradation of performance on the HV. At the same time, when the
usage cools down, operators enable those HVs back manually. It will be
useful to have a filter for the HVs based on thresholds defined for the
metrics - thus automating the manual work in a programmatic way.

Change-Id: Ie3c7ee1584e7ebcb238d19f7462ca4b6ba605b54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/96/257596/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Add new filter based on thresholds of metrics ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/metrics-threshold-filter Operators want to avoid scheduling more VMs on a host(HV), when the CPU usage on the HV is hot. A combination of metric weight and metrics-based filter, gives a nice way to order the HVs, while scheduling. But, it does not give a choice to exclude a HV, based on the usage. So, at present, operators resort to disable a host from scheduling to avoid further degradation of performance on the HV. At the same time, when the usage cools down, operators enable those HVs back manually. It will be useful to have a filter for the HVs based on thresholds defined for the metrics - thus automating the manual work in a programmatic way. Problem description =================== None Use Cases ---------- Nova should have a choice of scheduling filter to de-select a host, if the metrics on the host seem to be crossing some operator defined thresholds. This will save hosts from performance degradation during spikes. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Proposed change is to write a new scheduling filter to act on thresholds defined in config, for corresponding metric on the given host. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Metrics of a host is read in the beginning of the scheduler processing, as the compute_nodes are read. So, there is no extra DB operation/read for this filter. So there is no performance degradation expected while using this filter. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: suro-patz (Surojit Pathak) Other contributors: None. Work Items ---------- - Add a new CONF option for metrics thresholds. - Add the filter, and corresponding test code. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= None. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation for the new config section will be required to be added. References ========== The implementation is up for review and early feedback: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/254423/

subject: Baremetal migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-27 06:51:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/a1129fc94e95e9724f291c5ff9b03a6d011a8730', 'message': 'Baremetal migration and evacuation

There are two cases we need to handle when doing HA in Ironic:
1. When a baremetal is broken, start a new one to replace it.
   This is baremetal migration.
2. When a compute node is broken, evacuate all baremetal instances
   to another compute node. This is baremetal evacuation.

The Ironic BP below will implement the main functionality in Ironic.
And this spec will enable Nova Ironic driver to support it.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/bare-metal-node-n+1-redundancy

Change-Id: I2f6a4e66a7a62b41d66e13f6b9a953d5dd31c76e

commit_message:
Baremetal migration

When a baremetal node is broken, it should be migrated into other
redundant node. This feature should also depend on the improvement
in Ironic story which will be implemented by the following Ironic BP.
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/bare-metal-node-n+1-redundancy

And this spec will implement the integration of Ironic and nova about
this feature. i.e. it will meet the step-1 of blueprint
baremetal-migration-evacuation.

Change-Id: I2f6a4e66a7a62b41d66e13f6b9a953d5dd31c76e
Depends-on: I3776dd497e6b1d8cf4f7e59f8663d9d787c8d1f1
Implements: blueprint baremetal-migration-evacuation
Co-Authored-By: Tang Chen <chen.tang@easystack.cn>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/12/261812/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Support migration and evacuation for Ironic driver ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/baremetal-migration-evacuation This spec implements migrate() and evacuate() APIs in Ironic driver to migrate and evacuate baremetals. Problem description =================== Currently, migrate() and evacuate() APIs are not supported in ironic driver. This is because Ironic has not supported baremetal migration. For this reason, we are blocked to provide HA when using Ironic driver in Nova. In Ironic, a BP [1] has been posted. This BP will enable Ironic to switch one baremetal to another when the baremetal is broken. Based on this BP, Nova Ironic driver could call the Ironic API and implement migrate() and evacuate(). The definition of migration and evacuation in Ironic driver: - migration: Switch one baremetal to another baremetal, the instance on the compute node won't change. - evacuation: Evacuate all baremetal instances from one compute node to other compute nodes. This is a little different from libvirt driver, or other VM drivers. Use Cases --------- There are two cases: * Case 1: When a baremetal is broken, we need to do a migration to migrate one baremetal to another, which means boot another baremetal with the same shared volume and use this new baremetal to replace the broken one. In this case, the compute node will still run as before. * Case 2: When a compute node is broken, we will lose control to the baremetals on that node. So we need to do a evacuation to evacuate all baremetal instances on that broken node to another nodes so that we can still control the baremetals. In this case, the baremetals will still run as before. Proposed change =============== * Add an Ironic driver API to migrate a baremetal. * Add an Ironic driver API to evacuate all baremetal instances. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- This spec will implement migrate() and evacuate() APIs in Ironic driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Tang Chen (tangchen) Work Items ---------- * Implement the migrate() API in Ironic driver. * Implement the evacuate() API in Ironic driver. Dependencies ============ This spec depends on the following blueprint in ironic. * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/bare-metal-node-n+1-redundancy Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/bare-metal-node-n+1-redundancy History ======= None

commit_message:
Add compute node on the go

While working on multi-node network, when we need more
computation power, it is difficult to add compute node.
So we wish to provide a way to automatically add compute
node on the go.

Change-Id: I08c4a77831a47c41851f62126d53e2a76823e138
Implements: blueprint Add compute node on the go
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/52/301552/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================================== Add Compute node on the go ======================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-compute-node-on-the-go We need to provide a way to support for adding new compute node on the go through templates. Problem description =================== While working on multi-node network, when we need more computation power, it is difficult to add compute node. Always we have to do it manually. So we wish to provide a mechanism so that we can do it through templates that we can run from controller without manual intervention of the user. A template needs to feed into the orchestration tool(eg: heat) that will add new compute node into the openstack system without impacting the currently running VMs. Use Cases ---------- The Administrator will use this feature to add more computation power and make the VMs work as expected. Proposed change =============== A python file needs to be created on the controller node that will make the new compute node up and do all the setup functions like (updating the host file of Controller, Network). It will run the required commands to add the compute node on the controller node. For verification, we will check the controller node logs and in the logs if we get notification of the resource allocated to compute node , then compute node would be attached. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Atul Agarwal Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None
