commit_message:
Nova support for attached volume extend

Change-Id: I465f21cc5da3fc027cc7901ac8461b99d5a83f12
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/61/273961/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Spec - nova support to enable extension of an attached volume ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-support-attached-volume-extend Problem description =================== Currently a volume extension requires that a volume be in the available state. This requires an attached volume to be detached from a VM before the volume can be extended in size. This requires that a volume be brought offline from the standpoint of the application using the volume. Use Cases --------- A deployer wants to increase the size of a volume that is currently attached to a VM. Proposed change =============== Nova will be listening for attached volume extend notification from Cinder. When the notification is received Nova will trigger a rescanning of device on the host to discover the change in volume size. Alternatives ------------ NA. This blue print is in conjunction with the work being done on the Cinder extend attached volume Data model impact ----------------- No DB schema change involved. REST API impact --------------- No changes to the API interface. Security impact --------------- NA Notifications impact -------------------- NA Other end user impact --------------------- NA Performance Impact ------------------ NA Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will be able to extend their volumes without having to detach them. Developer impact ---------------- Driver owners may want to enable this feature in their driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: manas-mandlekar Other contributors: shyvenug@in.ibm.com Work Items ---------- Add notification listener that will call the os-brick extend_volume API to trigger the host kernel size information to be updated on the attached host. Dependencies ============ * os-brick https://review.openstack.org/#/c/243730/ Add extend_volume API to os-brick connector objects to allow updating the host kernel size information for an attached volume. * The Cinder API changes to allow extend of an attached volume Testing ======= Testing volume extend when a volume is attached to a VM and the same can be discovered on the host. Documentation Impact ==================== Additional documentation around Notification listener in Nova. References ========== None History ======= None .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

nova-api can check hypervisor availability based on boot params

Add an endpoint to determine which hypervisors fit a given set of parameters
similar to the nova create.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: I3c78f70f2a174ea220d12a145927e80146c8bf70
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/07/313607/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================================== nova-api can check hypervisor availability based on boot parameters =================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/hypervisor-availability Add an endpoint to determine which hypervisors fit a given set of parameters similar to the nova create. Problem description =================== From an administrator perspective, it may be hard to assert how many hosts are available for a given set of parameters like those used in nova create. So by invoking this endpoint and giving it the same a set of parameters, you receive a list of weighed hosts for which that configuration fits. Use Cases --------- For a given flavor, a deployer can know how many hosts are available to receive a new instance of that said flavor. Proposed change =============== I propose adding an endpoint to the nova REST api in this form: /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-hypervisors/schedule-test ``` { "schedule-test": { "hypervisor" : [ { "id": 1, "hypervisor_hostname": "shizzle", "weight": 100 } ] } } ``` The cli client should also support the command nova hypervisor-schedule-test ``` +----+---------------------+--------+ | ID | Hypervisor hostname | Weight | +----+---------------------+--------+ | 1 | shizzle | 100 | +----+---------------------+--------+ ``` And the python client client.hypervisors.schedule_test() ``` [ WeighedHypervisor(id=1, hostname="shizzle", weight=100) ] ``` Parameters should be the exact same parameters as nova create This operation will NOT reserve nor create any state change in any object. This will all be possible by reproducing/reusing the logic of the method nova.scheduler.filter_scheduler.FilterScheduler::_schedule by calling get_filtered_hosts and get_weighed_hosts. On the Cells topic, this should pass in the cells scheduling as if an instance was actually created. Posting to get preliminary feedback on the scope of this spec.

commit_message:
Adds nova spec instance-memory-snapshot

Change-Id: Iaf1d1b44c9b8592b661571d77d47fb2c487ab366
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/15/295415/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================== Providing Memory Snapshots for Instances ======================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/instance-memory-snapshot Develop the capability to create and revert memory snapshots for instances. Currently nova can create image snapshots, however it only captures the state of the file system, not the state of the memory. This topic has been proposed in previous versions, yet none of them have been fully integrated into openstack. There are several use cases for taking snapshots of memory, processor states, disks. and other devices. By developing a take/restore snapshot chaining capability, users will be able to quickly return a particular virtual machine state instead of booting a new instance, thus saving more time while testing. Note, this does not necessarily have to replace the current snapshot functionality; it would extend the capability. Problem description =================== Currently, when users snapshot an instance, only the state of the filesystem is captured. Without the memory or processor state captured in the snapshots, users must launch a new instance with the snapshot image, instead of working with the same instance. Also every time a snapshot is taken, a new image is created from that instance which consumes more space. Furthermore, it is time consuming for a new image to be created by an instance in taking a snapshot, and time consuming for a new instance to be launched to revert to that snapshot. Use Cases --------- If a developer is building a new system, for each new package that they want to test, they quickly could take a new chain snapshot. If an end user is testing malware, they would need to capture the memory state in order to properly understand it's entire life cycle. All users could maintain one instance with multiple snapshots instead of multiple images. Proposed change =============== A snapshot chaining system should be developed to manage the snapshots. The new snapshot extension would provide a chaining system that would allow users to snapshot, revert to specific snapshots in the chain, and remove snapshots. Each snapshot would include it's power state, disks, memory state, processor state, virtual devices, and any other devices. The openstack command would look like: :: $ openstack server state <command> <instance-uuid> Example: :: $ openstack server state list <instance-uuid> $ openstack server state merge <instance-uuid> $ openstack server state snapshot <instance-uuid> <snapshot-name> $ openstack server state revert <instance-uuid> <snapshot-uuid> $ openstack server state delete <instance-uuid> <snapshot-uuid/all> Alternatives ------------ Instead of developing a chaining mechanism, instances could have seperate snapshots that do not relate to the previous snapshot, thus removing snapshot trees. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Similar rest API functions need to be developed to match the openstack cli. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- 1. Implement rest api changes. 2. Implement the nova compute api changes. 3. Implement libvirt api changes. 4. Add instance snapshot states to DB. 5. Implement instnace snapshot state functions in DB API. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Document the new openstack commands. References ========== * Discussion on memory snapshots in openstack https://www.mail-archive.com/openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org/msg18966.html * Previous Blueprints https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-snapshot-vms https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-snapshots History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Add support for non-admin users to query their own deleted instances

Non-admin users should be able to query their own
instances no matter whether they have been deleted
or not. But the current nova didn't allow this.

This spec propose to support non-admin to query their
own deleted instances.

Blueprint: non-admin-check-own-deleted-instances

Change-Id: Ie055083f3237b3288ea714f76e4e8b9acb66df9a

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================= Allow non-admin user to check their own deleted instances ========================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/non-admin-check-own-deleted-instances Non-admin cloud users should be able to query all their instances no matter it has been deleted or not. Problem description =================== Currently Nova didn't allow non-admin users to query their own deleted instances. Query with ``status=deleted`` is forbidden for non-admin users and query with ``delted=true`` will be silently removed as it is not in the permitted action list for non-admin users. Use Cases --------- As an OpenStack cloud user, I may want to query all my instances no matter they are deleted or not. I may want to check the configuration of the previous deleted instances, etc. Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== Add support for non-admin users to list their own deleted instances, and the permit of this action can be controlled using policy files, the default will be allow non-admin users to check their own deleted instances. Alternatives ------------ Keep the current implementation and non-admins cannot check their own deleted instances. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- * URL: * /v2.1/servers/details?deleted=true * /v2.1/servers/details?status=deleted * Request method: * GET Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zhenyu Zheng Work Items ---------- 1. Add support for non-admins to query their own deleted instances. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== References ========== .. [1] Maillist discussion about inconstant behavior when list deleted instances: http://list.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-March/088021.html

commit_message:
Add direct upload feature for file glance backend

Change-Id: Ifb9397255fea8c8ee95ab179f864b7b1e6bb90a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/05/308805/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Add direct upload feature for file glance backend =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/direct-upload-for-file This blueprint aims to support for the direct upload feature for "glance image file backend" when taking vm snapshot. Problem description =================== Supporting for direct downloads of glance locations is already added by plug-in modules.[1] And this feature only can support downloading not uploading. In current version of nova if you take snapshot of a running server, nova will upload the image to glance server. If it creates multiple snapshot at the same time, glance server will receive heavy load and traffic. It would be better to upload directly to the backend store instead of sending all of the image size through glance server. Added new file upload scheme for Nova. With that change Nova can upload snapshot images directly from snapshot working directory to glance file backend. Use Cases --------- No changes to the typical end-user's request for vm snapshot Nova service just uses direct_url for uploading glance images. Proposed change =============== Instead of sending through glance node, nova-compute service can directly upload image from snapshot working directory to glance file backend. the workflow is simple as follows: 1. Create an image from vm snapshot.(nova image-create) 2. copy that image to glance file backend. 3. if anything failes in the process, the image will be uploaded through glance node as before. Failures will be reported in the form of stack traces in the nova compute logs. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jangpro2 Other contributors: cosmos0703,daeseong.kim,jihyun-song0829,raymon-ha Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ You need a newer version of glance as direct URL was added. Testing ======= The unit tests will of course cover the new code. As direct upload is enabled automatically, there is no need to change the tempest tests. And make sure that the direct url is used when configured conrrectly Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] Add plug-in modules for direct downloads of glance locations : https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37817/ History ======= None

commit_message:
VMware: server group policies in cluster

This will provide a mechanism to do instance placement with vcenter
cluster by ensuring the affinity and anti-affintity policies
at ESX host level.

Implements: blueprint vmware-placement-policy
Change-Id: I8c081f1dd52fae1c03c34595612a7f08b029270b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/05/237805/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== VMware: placement policies within cluster ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-placement-policy This will provide a mechanism to do instance placement with vcenter cluster by ensuring the affinity and anti-affintity policies at ESX host level. In addition, provide ability to do placement on a group of hosts. Problem description =================== Currently, nova scheduler sees a vcenter cluster as a compute node. Because of this abstraction, affinity placement policy is not guaranteed at ESX host level and anti-affinity policy could place maximum of only one instance per group on a cluster. This violates the user defined policies (in case of affinity rules) and impacts resource utilization within cluster. The proposal is to inspect the policies from server group object and automatically create rules on vcenter cluster to satisfy the placement policy at ESX host level. In addition, the notion of host aggregates is also not available at ESX host level because of using clusters. To support placement policies on a group/aggregate of ESX hosts, add a new image property "vmware_vm_group" which could be used do the placement based on the group policy defined on cluster." Use Cases ---------- Tenants want to place instances based on affinity (example: database and application servers) and anti-affinity (say, for fault tolerance) policy using nova VMware driver. This is a requirement for multi-tier Telco setups. Admins/tenants would want certain VNF workloads to run only on specific set of hosts within a cluster to meet SLA guarantees. Proposed change =============== The proposal is to leverage the server groups API for vm-vm affinity and anti-affinity policies within vcenter cluster. And add a new image metadata 'vmware_vm_group' that corresponds to vcenter vm group for vm-host placement policies. Currently, nova scheduler has the following filters to expresses affinity and anti-affinity rules between instances. 1. ServerGroupAffinityFilter 2. ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter These filters work in combination with server group API. Through server group API, tenants can specify the policies as 'affinity' or 'anti-affinity'. In VMware driver, the policy information will be retrieved and affinity/anti-affinity rules will be created automatically on the vc cluster. This would make the behavior of ServerGroupAffinityFilter and ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter similar to other reference drivers. For vm-host placement policy, VMware driver will read the image metadata 'vmware_vm_group' and associate the instance to the corresponding vm group folder on vcenter cluster. The vm-host policy defined within cluster can then take care of placement on specific host(s). Alternatives ------------ Given the abstraction of cluster as a compute node in VMware VC driver, there are no other alternatives. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- For vm-vm affinity/anti-affinity policy, there is no change in deployment. The following examples demonstrates how existing commands can be used. Users would create server group with a policy as: nova server-group-create --policy <affinity|anti-affinity> <group name> Now, an instance can be deployed by passing scheduler hint group=<uuid of server instance group> nova boot --image <image id> --flavor <flavor id> --hint group=<uuid of server instance group> <instance name> For vm-host placement policy, admins have to update image metadata 'vmware_vm_group'. Here is a sample format: glance image-update <image id> --property vmware_vm_group=<vm group name> Then booting an instance with this image would automatically place it on corresponding vm group within vcenter. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: gjayavelu Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Define new image metadata 'vmware_vm_group' * Modify VMware driver to parse the 'vmware_vm_group' image property and place the vm on corresponding vm group * Modify VMware driver to get server group object, read the policy and automatically create rules on vcenter cluster Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Functional tests are better for this feature because it requires querying configuring vcenter directly. Currently, there are no functional tests for VMware driver. Defining functional tests for VMware driver may be outside the scope of this spec. Documentation Impact ==================== The user documentation for VMware driver should be updated about the new image metadata 'vmware_vm-group'. References ========== vcenter placement rules: https://goo.gl/5fdT63 History ======= Optional section for Mitaka intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Allow creating VMs without powering it up

For flexibility, performance, and automation,
a user may want to create a VM without powering it up.

Blueprint: allow-create-vm-without-starting-it
Change-Id: I0f01165235e992aab0e580622a7e96cc9683afde
APIImpact
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/24/274424/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= API for creating a VM without powering it up ============================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/allow-create-vm-without-starting-it Allow new VMs to be created without powering them up, but simply create a shut-off VM. This is to allow the end-user further flexibility, performance, and automation. Problem description =================== A user may want, or benefit, from creating a VM without powering it up, but leave it shutoff. The "create-server" API should support creating a VM, and leaving it shut-off. Use Cases --------- * An end-user might want to deploy a significant number of machines all at once. Powering-up all the VMs would take a great deal of resources, and would slow down the process. * A cloud-admin sets up an image that sets different configuration on first boot. The admin may want to create VMs that are allocated for a user, then send him the vm-id, so he can boot the VM for the first time and configure them. Proposed change =============== Add a boolean parameter to the "create-server" API that states whether the VM should be powered-up or not. For backward-compatibility, the parameter is optional, and the default is to powerup the VM. This parameter will be passed to the compute node, and from there to the driver, which will powerup the VM or not. Thus, all drivers should be changed to support the new flag. Alternatives ------------ * Adding a cloud-init script that shuts-off the VM as soon as it's powered up. Problems with this approach is that the machine may have configurations on first boot (see user-cases), and that not all VMs support cloud-init. * Waiting for the VM to be active, and then powering it off. Problems with this approach is a big overhead to create VMs, and the configurations on the first boot. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The "create-server" API would be added a new, optional, boolean parameter - "powerup". This boolean value determines whether to power up the new VM. The default for the parameter, if not passed, is true. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- python-novaclient would need to be updated to support the new "powerup" parameter Performance Impact ------------------ When the VM will be created without powering it up, the vm-creation process would be faster. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- All the drivers should support the new "powerup" boolean flag on the "spawn" function. If it False, the driver would create the VM and allocate resources, but won't actually power it up. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Shoham Peller <shoham.peller@stratoscale.com> Other contributors: Help would be needed on the non-libvirt drivers. Work Items ---------- * Add the "powerup" flag to the "create-server" API and schema. * Pass the parameter to the compute-node and to the driver * Implement support for not powering-up on the different drivers. * Set the state of the VM according to the user's request Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests, functional API tests. Tempest test for creating a VM without powering it up. Documentation Impact ==================== The support for the new flag when creating a server will be documented. References ========== * http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-January/084551.html

commit_message:
Committing the specifications for support-flavor-update blueprint

Change-Id: I33ee2198bdf0fd96dcf87cc9d5b348382d9693fe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/59/322859/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Support flavor update =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/update-flavor Problem description =================== Currently, OpenStack can only update flavor extra_spec but not vcpu, memory or disk and some customer might want to update those attributes for the flavor at run time so a new API such as "update" was needed to support this. Refer to https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1180664 for detail. Use Cases --------- Admin should be able to update the existing as well as newly created flavours. The current implementation doesn;t allow the updation of flavours. Via horizon, when updating the flavors , the current implementation deletes the existing flavor and creates a new flavor. This use case consists of updating the flavor attributes. Proposed change =============== The change is creating a new "flavor-update" command in nova shell.py. The CLI nova flavor-update will call newly defined update function in File: /opt/stack/nova/nova/compute/flavors.py. The compute function will call the DB call in File : /opt/stack/nova/nova/db/api.py, which in turn changes the flavor attribute. Alternatives ------------ Nothing Data model impact ----------------- Nothing REST API impact --------------- Creation of PUT call in nova as "/{project_id}/flavors/{flavorid}" Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- Nothing Other end user impact --------------------- End user will able to update the flavor via nova command line. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: milind-joshi1988 Work Items ---------- Creation of the client code for "nova flavor-update" call. API creation to accept the "nova flavor-update" PUT requests from nova. Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Unit and integration tests. Documentation Impact ==================== OpenStack documentation of nova for flavor-update call. References ========== History =======

We need to move calculation of 'ComputeNode.disk_vailable_least' to
resource tracker to solve this problem.

'ComputeNode.disk_vailable_least' to resource tracker, because only
the resource tracker holding the global resource lock knows the current
usage of resources since it can take both existing instances and
ongoing migrations into account.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L5416
[2]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/virt/xenapi/driver.py#L458

Related-Bug: #1517442
Blueprint move-disk-available-least-calculation-to-rt

Change-Id: Ib99006c78cf8f0db1608a78fbec60d5b568a1480
"}]
commit_message:
Move calculation of 'disk_available_least' to ResourceTracker

Currently in libvirt[1] and xenapi[2] driver, method
'get_available_resource()' will report 'disk_available_least' in its
return value.

However, libvirt and xenapi driver only take the instances known by
hypervisor into account but ignore the instances being migrate to/from
the host.

To solve this problem, We need to move the calculation of
'ComputeNode.disk_vailable_least' to resource tracker, because only
the resource tracker holding the global resource lock knows the current
usage of resources since it can take both existing instances and
ongoing migrations into account.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L5416
[2]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/virt/xenapi/driver.py#L458

Related-Bug: #1517442
Blueprint move-disk-available-least-calculation-to-rt

Change-Id: Ib99006c78cf8f0db1608a78fbec60d5b568a1480
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/72/293272/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================== Move calculation of disk_available_least to resource tracker ============================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/move-disk-available-least-calculation-to-rt Move the calculation of 'ComputeNode.disk_available_least' out of the compute drivers and into resource tracker. Problem description =================== Currently in libvirt[1] and xenapi[2] driver, the 'get_available_resource()' method will report 'disk_available_least' in return value. [1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L5416 [2]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/virt/xenapi/driver.py#L458 However, libvirt and xenapi driver only take the instances known by hypervisor into account but ignore the instances being migrate to/from the host, which is because ongoing migrations are invisible to compute drivers. We need to move calculation of 'ComputeNode.disk_vailable_least' to resource tracker to solve this problem. Proposed change =============== Add 'local_gb_allocated' field to nova.objects.ComputeNode to record the total virtual disk size has been allocated on compute node. In compute drivers, modify the 'get_available_resource()' method to drop calculation of 'disk_available_least'. In resource_tracker, add logic to update 'compute_node.local_gb_allocated' field in 'ResourceTracker._update_usage()' method. Since '_update_usage()' method will be called to update the resource usage for each instance and migration, we can make sure that every instance on the host and every instance being migrated to/from the host will be taken into account for calculation of 'disk_available_least'. Eventually, just like the calculation of 'free_ram_mb' and 'free_disk_gb'[3], we can get 'disk_available_least' value with below expression: compute_node.disk_available_least = (compute_node.local_gb - compute_node.local_gb_allocated) [3]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/13.0.0.0b3/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L714 Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <yuywz> Work Items ---------- Add 'local_gb_allocated' field in nova.objects.ComputeNode. Drop logic for calculating 'disk_available_least' in compute drivers. Add logic for calculating 'disk_available_least' in 'ResourceTracker._update_usage()' method. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add new test case in nova.tests.unit.compute.test_resource_tracker.py to test the calculation of 'disk_available_least'. Some minor adjustment needed to be performed on existing test cases. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== Originally reported as a bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1517442 Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/move-disk-available-least-calculation-to-rt

commit_message:
Propose blueprint scalable-metadata to Newton

Spec for blueprint: scalable-metadata

Change-Id: If747a48d56f97b963bdac3bf63966b625fbe718c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/53/317353/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Scalable Metadata ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/scalable-metadata This blueprint introduces a scalable implementation for metadata service which can support serving large amount of metadata requests from instances at any time. Problem description =================== When thousands of instances are requesting metadata service concurrently, it will show performance downgrade which significantly increases response time. When it is necessary to create the object after the cache invalidates, DB calls in InstanceMetadata#init which fetches instance information will produce side affects to the response time. Many deployments still rely on MySQLdb for DB calls. It has been widely acknowledged that MySQLdb does not work well with eventlet. This becomes a major issue in OpenStack as almost every OpenStack service is built on eventlet. eventlet needs everything to be "green" so the application is able to provide networking concurrency based on event-driven networking I/O, but the C extension in MySQLdb prevents eventlet from doing that. Every DB call blocks the whole process until the response arrives as the C extension still uses blocking I/O. Everything including every greenlet is also put into sleep during the blocking time, which is the reason for a low concurrency in such a case. Despite the transition to other pure-python driver is ongoing, it is unlikely to find an alternative to have the same performance as MySQLdb at the moment. It still cannot be considered to be a valid fix. The goal is to provide a scalable metadata service which can support a very large scale of concurrent requests within a relatively small response time. Use Cases --------- * End User: End user may send large amounts of metadata requests not only at instance launch but any time * Deployer: Deployers may choose the expected backend driver based on the assumption of concurrent metadata requests and install the requirements in their environment Proposed change =============== It has been cleared that we should limit the count of DB calls when implementing metadata. We will use key-value DB instead of relational DB to store metadata as metadata items fits into the category of less-write-frequently-read data. The whole metadata service will be completely rewritten. A new RPC API to create/update/delete metadata is introduced in metadata service. * When the instance is being created, nova-compute will call the RPC API to create the metadata items and store them into Redis. * When nova instance metadata is updated through nova meta update command, nova-api will call the RPC API to update the values in Redis. * When the instance is being destroy, the values in Redis will also be cleared. * A periodic task to recover metadata for all existed instances can be triggered when necessary. It can be used to detect missing items when data stored in Redis are purged or reconstructed. It may produce a very short time window of waiting on launch in such a case, but it will reduce the pain during a version upgrade as data in Redis no longer needs to be migrated. To provide backward compatibility for those environments in which frequent requests on metadata are not required, there is also a classic driver which does the same thing as before this change. Alternatives ------------ * eventlet provides tpool to wrap DB calls in separated native threads. However, it has been verified that eventlet may accidentally wake up greenlet in other threads which may cause the process to hang eventually. Upstream eventlet does not contain a workable fix as for now. * Pure-Python driver like pymysql might be another option. However, during a simple verification on the same environment which contains only the change to switch from MySQLdb to pymysql, the response time still increases to the same level as MySQLdb when the load goes up. * The root cause for the issue is that DB driver does not work well with eventlet. There are some discussions to replace eventlet + monkey patch with threaded implementation upstream but the impact is still unknown and does not seem to be happening lately. Data model impact ----------------- There is no impact to the current relational DB data model as new data objects are stored in Redis. Data model needs to be flexible and efficient, which means data items should be able to be modified respectively with less keys. Also, as Redis does not support nested data types, some items which can not be simply represented with strings may need to be packed into other types. For example, data represented in the following JSON:: { "meta-data": { "tenant-id": "blablabla", "placement": {"availability-zone": "nova"} }, "user-data": "blablabla" } can be represented with the following structure: .. list-table:: Data structure example :header-rows: 1 * - Redis key - Type - Value * - PREFIX:ec2 - set - "meta-data", "user-data" * - PREFIX:ec2:meta-data - set - "items", "placement" * - PREFIX:ec2:meta-data:items - map - {"tenant-id": "blablabla"} * - PREFIX:ec2:meta-data:placement - map - {"availability-zone": "nova"} * - PREFIX:ec2:user-data - string (base64 encoded) - "blablabla" The data model in Redis is designed as below: * Instance data cache .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 * - Redis key - Type - Value * - instance:X - map - instance properties which can represented as string * EC2 meta data / user data .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 * - Redis key - Type - Value * - instance:X:ec2 - set - key set to indicate whether the subkeys exists * - instance:X:ec2:meta-data - set - key set to indicate whether the subkeys exists * - instance:X:ec2:meta-data:items - map - meta data items which can be represented with string * - instance:X:ec2:meta-data:block-device-mapping - map - instance block device mapping * - instance:X:ec2:meta-data:placement - map - instance placement in map representation * - instance:X:ec2:meta-data:public-keys - map - instance public keys * - instance:X:ec2:meta-data:security-groups - map - instance security groups * - instance:X:ec2:user-data - string (base64 encoded) - instance user data in base 64 encoded string * OpenStack meta data / user data .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 * - Redis key - Type - Value * - instance:X:openstack - set - key set to indicate whether the subkeys exists * - instance:X:openstack:meta_data - set - key set to indicate whether the subkeys exists * - instance:X:openstack:meta_data:items - map - metadata items which can be represented in string * - instance:X:openstack:meta_data:public_keys - map - instance public keys * - instance:X:openstack:meta_data:meta - map - instance specific meta data * - instance:X:openstack:meta_data:extra_meta data - map - instance extra meta data * - instance:X:openstack:vendor_data - string - instance vendor data * - instance:X:openstack:user_data - string - instance user data * - instance:X:openstack:password - string - instance password REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- As some of the metadata drivers may have external dependencies like Redis, deployers may pay extra attentions when a trust-able environment is required. Currently we do not have sensitive data stored in these external dependencies. Another blueprint will be introduced to apply encryption when concerned. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ * A periodic task to scan all missing instances is introduced and may slow down the performance when it recovers the metadata from DB. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployer would have to choose the driver to use: :code:`metadata_driver = driver_name`. Some metadata driver have specific options which requires the deployer to configure them properly. As for now, the following two options are required for Redis driver. * servers: Redis server list in host:port format Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: zlao Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- 1. Refactoring metadata implementation * Moving some metadata code to new filters 2. Add metadata driver and RPC API 3. Create/Update/Remove metadata at appropriate timing 4. Periodic task to rebuild metadata in Redis Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Testing this feature requires to build a new image with constantly requesting metadata when instance is alive. It may be also necessary to profile the response time of every metadata request and query the CPU usage of nova metadata process during the testing. Documentation Impact ==================== New options need to be added to Operations Guide. References ========== * Redis (http://redis.io/) * DB calls with tpool (https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/juno/add-tpool-proxy-wrapper.html) * pymysql Evaluation (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/PyMySQL_evaluation) * Dropping eventlet (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/164035/) History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Copy console logs for block live migration

Current implementation of block live migration causes
lost of console.log file content. Ability to copy logs
needs to be added to preserve log data.

Change-Id: Ib42ec2e08a4cfb297ed7602fba74df2f848fcc31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/09/298809/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Copy console log file for block live miration ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/console-logs-block-migration During block live migration console logs are lost. This happens implicitly for cloud operator. So as logs are part of instance data they should be copied either. Problem description =================== Live migration that uses libvirt driver totally relies on libvirt in copying log files data of instance. Libvirt doesn't do anything for copying log files just create new entry on destination node, so all logs of instance are lost. Logs should be copied with instance on destination node as another instance related data e.g image. Use Cases --------- Operator will able to observe console logs after block live migration. Proposed change =============== With this spec we propose to copy log file with another instance related data simply by copying it to temporary file on destination via scp and then substitute during post_live_migration_on_destination. Alternatives ------------ Newer version of libvirt will possible include virtlogd deamon that handles log related issues such as rotating. It can simplify log copying process, so so instead of copying single file and ensure that it was substituted successfully without any data races just copy console.log.x files from source to destination. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- Console logs may contain secure user data. Logs are copied via ssh to prevent stealing of that information. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- After block live migration user will be able to observer instance logs that were made before migration. Performance Impact ------------------ Long lived instances may produce large amount of logs, so copying of them may slow down migration process. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: gstepanov Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add function to copy logs on source node and send them to destination. * Update post_live_migration_at_destination to substitute log file created by libvirt with logfile copied from source. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Please discuss the important scenarios needed to test here, as well as specific edge cases we should be ensuring work correctly. For each scenario please specify if this requires specialized hardware, a full openstack environment, or can be simulated inside the Nova tree. Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Power and thermal metrics spec

This spec introduces the detail of these metrics and also the usages

blueprint:  power-thermal-metrics

Change-Id: I75d21b1bd759f56a97a421bbe0f121b38c4b8321
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/95/312295/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Report host thermal and power as metrics in Nova ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/power-thermal-metrics This spec proposes to introduce host power and thermal related metrics, which can be used to perform intelligent scheduling to improve the cooling/power efficiency. These metrics are Outlet temperature (Exhaust Air),Inlet temperature, Airflow, System power and CPU power. Nova-compute should be able to expose these on every node which supports IPMI and NodeManager3.0 technology. These metrics can be leveraged in Openstack by exposing it as a monitor. This will follow a similar approach as the already existing monitor for CPU. Outlet temperature is the temperature of exhaust air of the host, the unit is degree C. It can be used to measure the current thermal status of hosts, it should be in the allowable temperature range. If it's out of range, and it should be filtered. Inlet temperature is the temperature of the supply air to the host, the unit is also degree C. It can be used to measure the thermal status of the environment, it also should be in range, too low or too high are not good for performance of host and cooling efficiency of DC. Airflow is another important metric to measure the fan status inside the physical server, the unit is 0.1 CFM(Cubic Feet per Minute). It should be dynamic adjusted according to the inlet temperature and current system power. Otherwise, something bad happens. System power and CPU power is the current power consumption of host, the unit is watts. Problem description =================== In current Data Center infrastructure, thermal and power metrics become more and more important to improve cooling efficiency and power efficiency. The scheduler need to be more intelligent, it should not only consider the cpu/memory/io utilization, but also the current thermal conditions and power consumptions. Use Cases ---------- * Prioritize scheduling VMs on hypervisors in cooler regions of the DC. Reduced power consumption, increased reliability, improve cooling efficiency. * Filter out the hypervisors with high outlet temperature, which may have heavy workloads or fan issue. * Scheduling VMs to balance the workloads based on power consumption curve to reduce the power consumption. * More intelligent scheduling based on Machine learning. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Estimated changes are going to be in the following places: * Extend the Resource monitor framework to implement a optional monitor for thermal and power metrics via IPMI, much in line with the CPU monitor. * Introduce a nova object model representation of the data. The Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) is a set of computer interface specifications for an autonomous computer subsystem that provides management and monitoring capabilities independently of the host system's CPU, firmware (BIOS or UEFI) and operating system. IPMI defines a set of interfaces used by system administrators for out-of-band management of computer systems and monitoring of their operation. Ipmitool is a good choice to get the thermal and power metrics via IPMI. https://sourceforge.net/projects/ipmitool/. Alternatives ------------ The alternative is to access the IPMI device directly but that would be big effort to implement IPMI protocol. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The performance impact is negligible since this Monitor is not enabled by default and the data is aggregated by the hardware and accessed via IPMI. Openstack will call this API once a minute with an option to increase the interval. Other deployer impact --------------------- The following packages should be added to the system: * ipmitool Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <junjie-huang> Other assignee: Work Items ---------- 1. Use ipmitool to obtain these metrics. 2. Perform data sampling in the monitoring code. 3. Create metrics plugin to sample the metrics data. Dependencies ============ Physical hosts need to support IPMI and NodeMananger3.0 should be Intel Xeon E5-7 platform or upper Testing ======= The changes will be exercised through unit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/servers/ipmi/ipmi-home.html History ======= None

commit_message:
Add distinct-subset-shard-scheduler spec

Add the ability to split nova-compute nodes into a group of distinct
subsets, and have requests routed to a separate nova-scheduler
cluster for each subset.

blueprint distinct-subset-shard-scheduler

Change-Id: I25b82568630c7672b8b73b6d4f687ca20dcb7188
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/19/313519/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Distinct Subset Shard Scheduler ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/distinct-subset-shard-scheduler Add the ability to split nova-compute nodes into a group of distinct subsets, and have requests routed to a separate nova-scheduler cluster for each subset. Problem description =================== In many deployments the hypervisor hosts can be grouped into distinct subsets, where ever user build request can only be served by one of those distinct subsets. A common example is having some flavors that have local ephemeral storage from SSDs with 10Gb networking, another set of hosts having spinning disks and 1Gb based networking, and a set of ironic controlled bare metal hosts. In this situation, deployers have to manage the capacity in each of these subsets largely independently. It often leads to wanting different scheduling rules for each subset. For example, you may want to isolate a set of hosts just for real time workloads. While much of this can be done with existing filters, its very messy. Having a separate scheduler, with a separate set of rules for each subset, is an easier metal model. However, the main motivation around dedicated separate schedulers is so you can scale out the number of nova-schedulers in each of the host subsets to match the scale requirements of each subset of hosts. Existing cells v1 users are used to have separate scheduling rules for each cell, and scaling out the scheduler separately in each cell. Adopting this subset scheduler will ease the transition from cells v1 to cells v2. The big change between this proposal and the existing cells v1 scheduler is that it is not a hierarchical scheduler, its a sharded shared state scheduler. There are issues with the cells v1 scheduler because of the need to child cells to report capacity to the parent cell, this scheduler in this proposal avoids those problems. Another bit difference is while the subset can be aligned with cells boundaries, that is not a required. You can now add a cell that has a mix of hosts from each type of host type. Use Cases --------- * Provide different scheduling rules for each distinct subsets of hosts * Help scale out the scheduler by making use of an existing sharding pattern * Ease the transition from cells v1 to cells v2 Proposed change =============== There are several key steps: * Setup multiple scheduler clusters. So we need the ability to create new scheduler database for each cluster * Compute hosts configured to send their scheduler calls and info to a specific scheduler cluster. Each compute node must only be a member of one scheduler cluster. * API conductor has configuration that assigns a uuid to a scheduler connection URL * Ability to map a specific flavor to scheduler cluster uuid. We could add this in flavor extra specs, "scheduler_cluster"=<uuid> where the uuid can be used to look up the scheduler configuration * The API conductor can now use the flavor information, and its configuration to route build requests to the correct scheduler. Should the flavor not have a cluster uuid specified, we fallback to the api cell database and RPC to use the "default" scheduler. Alternatives ------------ We could stick with the limitation of a single scheduler per Nova region, and focus making that scale. However we loose the non-scale related benefits of this model. We could re-implement cells v1 style hierarchical scheduler, but that has proven to perform very poorly when you have a large number of concurrent requests for a single flavor, particularly when the free capacity is split across several cells. We would also loose the flexibility that the scheduler subsets can span multiple cells, and a single cell can be in multiple host subsets. This model has a static mapping from flavors to scheduler clusters. We could allow an arbitrary function to take a request_spec and return the uuid of the correct scheduler cluster. While more general, its much harder to use. This could be a future addition. This leaves the discussion of migrating cells v1 users to this new scheduler as a separate topic. Data model impact ----------------- We need to store: * the mapping from flavor to scheduler subset * the list of scheduler subsets and AMQP connection URLs (this could be in CONF) REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- Scheduler notifications may not come from different hosts. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ This will help deployers scale out by sharding the load between multiple scheduler clusters. Other deployer impact --------------------- TODO There needs to be a new database created for each scheduler cluster. This also needs to be configured on every compute host. There also needs to be a mapping added to the flavor, so we know which cluster each build request should go to. Developer impact ---------------- No long term impact. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: John Garbutt (IRC: johnthetubaguy) Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ Moving the scheduler related DB tables out of the compute cell DB. While not dependent on, this conflicts with the Scheduler REST API work. Testing ======= We should add in tree functional tests for the routing between schedulers. We could look at multiple schedulers in the gate. Documentation Impact ==================== Admin docs updates required. References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Consistent Success Reporting

We propose to implement consistent reporting of successful API
actions roughly along the lines discussed in the "Tasks Manifesto".

This involves reporting the finish time and status for every instance
action.

blueprint consistent-instance-actions

Change-Id: I811b6fff1da2056ef8d4b411f42cefcd1fed555e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/48/248248/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Consistent Instance Actions =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/consistent-instance-actions We propose to implement consistent reporting of all successful API actions along the lines discussed in the "Tasks Manifesto". Problem description =================== For a detailed description, see [NPS1]_. Briefly, we want to improve the reporting Nova does for long running asychronous actions. In order to narrow the scope of the problem, this spec proposes improving the reporting for all successful API actions. Use Cases --------- As a User, I want a consistent interface by which I can determine that a long-running asynchronous action has completed successfully. As a Deployer, I want a to be able to do better monitoring of my cloud with respect to long-running asynchronous server actions, whether by traditional log reading or by a tool such as StackTach or Ceilometer that consumes notifications. Proposed change =============== There are three related changes: #. Ensure every successfully completed asynchronous API operation is correctly reported via the existing os-instance-actions API [OSD1]_. #. During Mitaka, versioned notifications will be introduced [NSP1]_. We will want to make sure that for each successfully completed asynchronous API operation, the correct start and end notifications are emitted. #. Finally, we want to ensure that consistent messages are logged when actions have started and completed. Alternatives ------------ We could curse the darkness instead of light a candle. There's really not an alternative, we should be doing this already. The scope could be reduced by not doing all three changes described above, but we really do need to support all three scenarios. Data model impact ----------------- No data model impact. REST API impact --------------- No REST API impact. Security impact --------------- No security impact. Notifications impact -------------------- Missing notifications may be added. Other end user impact --------------------- No other end user impact. Performance Impact ------------------ No significant performance impact is anticipated. Basically, this change is making existing functionality more consistent. Other deployer impact --------------------- No other deployer impact. Developer impact ---------------- No developer impact. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: toan-nguyen Other contributors: brian-rosmaita Work Items ---------- #. Audit all available Nova API actions and make sure they are represented in the os-instance-actions API. #. Make sure successfully completed actions have start/end information communicated to the os-instance-actions API. #. Make sure successfully completed actions have notifications emitted at the start and end of the action. #. Make sure successfully completed actions are consistently logged at both the start and end of the action. Dependencies ============ This work depends in part on the approved spec "Versioned notification API" [NSP1]_. Testing ======= Since we're dealing with the "happy path" here (i.e., successful server actions), there should be existing tests that can be modified to test the changes described herein. Documentation Impact ==================== We don't anticipate much documentation impact. This is expected behavior that isn't currently occurring. References ========== .. [NPS1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/221280/ .. [NSP1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/versioned-notification-api.html .. [OSD1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#os-instance-actions-v2.1 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Add newton spec for ordered filter scheduler

The current filter scheduler is hard to configure once you get past a
very small number of filters and weights. Also the difference between
filters and weights causes friction when wanting to tweak the scheduler
configuration.

This spec proposes a method of using purely filter functions to order
the lists of hosts, in a way that seems easier to understand for
deployers. To ease the transition, the weight based system is kept to
break a tie in any of the preferences.

This renames scheduler_default_filters to scheduler_filters_requirements
and adds the new config option scheduler_filters_preferences

Change-Id: Ica0c7c0c57f230b2358ba5db23bc14eba8f1d291
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/23/256323/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Drop Scheduler Weights and use only Ordered Filters =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ordered-filter-scheduler Proposal for a new simpler to configure scheduler that works only with an order set of filters. Problem description =================== The configuration for the current filter scheduler is surprisingly hard to reason about. Many times its only with simulations you fully understand what the current configuration means. Currently implementing the option for a hard vs soft requirement means you need to implement only a filter or a weight. Use Cases --------- Non technical product want to understand the intent of the current scheduler configuration, from an end user perspective, so they can participate in evolving the scheduler's settings. It should be simple to choose between a hard and soft test on the property of a host, when deciding if that host is suitable for a server to be built on it. Proposed change =============== This backlog spec proposes a new metal model for the scheduler, and gives a rough idea of how that might be implemented. The scheduler is trying to decide which hosts are the best candidates for a particular server build (or move) request, given the current information it has about that host and the request. As the cloud operator, consider there being a set of tests to decide if a host is suitable or not for a given build request. For backwards compatibility reasons, lets call that a filter. The operator can now come up with a preference order for those tests. The tests you care about the most (the first tests), will be hard requirements. An example would be having enough resources on the host for the build request. At some point, you switch from hard requirements to soft requirements. This leaves us with a ordered list of soft requirements, and an order list of hard requirements. The order of the hard requirements will be to rule out as many hosts as possible as quickly as possible, to improve the efficiency of the tests. For the soft requirements, you to see what tests all the remaining hosts pass. To compare what is a better fit, we can use the ordered list to generate a bit field, and you can sort the list using the number generated from the bit field. Observe that in this system, it is a simple configuration change to change from a hard requirement to a soft requirement, because all tests are written as simple boolean operations that match the current host_passes function in the existing scheduler's filters. Please note, this is not aiming to be equally expressive as the existing system, it is aiming to be easier to understand. Alternatives ------------ The normalizing of the weights attempted to help make the filter scheduler easier to understand. But that created other issues. A possible extension of this scheduler, so it is more expressive, is to have ways for flavor extra_specs to influence the preference order. You could configure a default preference ordering, and some named preferences orders and reference those in the flavor. For simplicity, this has been excluded from this backlog specification. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Unknown Other deployer impact --------------------- This could be implemented as a parallel alternative to the current filter scheduler. For ease of transition, its possible existing filters could be the new ordered filter scheduler. Either way, the current proposal would have a massive impact on the deployer if they chose to adopt the new ordered filter scheduler. Developer impact ---------------- Two schedulers to maintain. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: John Garbutt (johnthetubaguy) Work Items ---------- TBC Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This would need to have some functional testing, ideally by moving some of the gate jobs to the new scheduler system. Documentation Impact ==================== Need to document the new scheduler, its concepts, and how to configure it. References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

Change-Id: Ia883bd3e4c2e2657fa365aa64ddebc62353436a2

commit_message:
Device tag - pci address mapping in image metadata.

This feature will allow users to express device role tag - pci address mappings
in image metadata. During creation of a instance devices referenced by device
tags will be configured to have pci address specified in the mapping.

Change-Id: Ia883bd3e4c2e2657fa365aa64ddebc62353436a2
Blueprint: image-prop-pci-mappings
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/64/309464/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Device tag - pci address mapping in image metadata ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/image-prop-pci-mappings This feature will allow users to express device role tag : pci address mappings in image metadata. During creation of a instance devices referenced by device tags will be configured to have pci address specified in the mapping. Problem description =================== The `virt-device-role-tagging blueprint`__ addresses the problem of identifying devices in the guest. It allows to tag network interfaces and block devices with arbitrary tags and then exposes those tags to the guest with information on how to identify the tagged device in guest. This approach requires the applications running in VM to be modified in order to understand information passed in metadata. None of applications available today are able to work with this new interface. Existing applications often require assignment of application specific PCI addresses to network interfaces present in the guest. Assigning specific PCI addresses to network interfaces in the guest is not supported by Nova, hence deployment of such applications with Nova is not possible. __ virt-device-role-tagging-bp Use Cases --------- The application the tenant wants to run requires specific network interfaces to appear at specific virtual PCI addresses. For example the application expects the management interface to appear at PCI address 00:02.0 and two dataplane interfaces, dataplane1 and dataplane2,to appear at 00:03.0 and 00:04.0. The tenant needs to be able to specify applications requirements in image metadata and identify the network interfaces using virtual device role tagging. Then virt driver should use application requirements from image metadata and device role tags to configure the VM accordingly. Proposed change =============== We are proposing to add new image metadata property 'hw_pci_mappings'. With this property the user would specify application requirements for pci addressing of virtual devices, using device role tags to identify the devices. The 'hw_pci_mappings' image metadata property would be a mapping of device role tags and virtual pci addresses. For example: :: hw_pci_mappings = "mgmt_if":"00:02.0","nfv1":"00:03.0","nfv2":"00:04.0" The flow for the user to use this feature would be: Set the image metadata properties: :: glance image-update nfv_vnf_image \ --property hw_pci_mappings = \ "mgmt_if":"00:02.0","nfv1":"00:03.0","nfv2":"00:04.0" Boot a virtual machine using nfv_vnf image and tag the interfaces: :: nova boot \ --image nfv_vnf_image \ --flavor m1.large \ --nic net-id=12121,tag=mgmt_if --nic net-id=12345,tag=nfv1 \ --nic net-id=56789,tag=nfv2 \ mynfvapp The virt drivers will be extended to match tags from image metadata to tags from instance and configure the devices pci addresses accordingly. The initial implementation will be done for the Libvirt driver. Additionally this feature could be controlled via a configuration option, to let administrators choose whether it should be enabled in their deployment. Alternatives ------------ There are two alternatives to consider. First is to not implement this feature and wait till VNF vendors support virtual device role tagging in their applications. This can lead to additional costs for companies deploying NFV with OpenStack or push them towards other cloud orchestration frameworks. Second alternative is to let users specify pci address requirements via REST API instead of the image metadata. We think it doing it via image metadata fits better the usecase and matches existing uses of image metadata properties. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Przemyslaw Czesnowicz Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- - Add new image metadata property - Modify Libvirt virt driver to support 'hw_pci_mappings' property Dependencies ============ This feature depends on `virtual-device-role-tagging feature`__ being implemented in Nova. __ virt-device-role-tagging-bp Testing ======= Intel NFV CI would be extended to test this feature. Documentation Impact ==================== New image metadata property would have to be documented. References ========== .. _virt-device-role-tagging-bp: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/virt-device-role-tagging .. _virt-device-role-tagging-spec: https://review.openstack.org/284091

support auto-converge for live migration

This spec describes the blueprint live-migrate-support-auto-converge

APIImpact

Co-Authored-By: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/58/248358/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== support auto coverge for live migration ========================================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-migrate-support-auto-converge When using live migrations, an operator might want to have a possibility to increase success chance of migration with busy enterprise workloads on their instance. This spec proposes a new opition auto-converge for live migration. Problem description =================== Some busy enterprise workloads hosted on large sized VM's tend to dirty memory faster than the transfer rate achieved via live guest migration. Despite some good recent improvements (& using dedicated 10Gig NICs between hosts) the live migration may NOT converge. In severe cases, heavy workloads will prevent live migration from finishing. In some cases, operator can tolerate pause VM during live migration to stop memory writes on a VM. And there is a BP support this feature. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/245543 But in another cases, the user want to keep the their workloads on their vm uninterrupted, they need a new mechenical auto-converge to satisfy their requirement. Use Cases ---------- As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I would like do the live migration for some purpose, such as hypervisor load-balance or save energy. To ensure the SLA uninterrupted business, I observe there's still heavy workloads on the VM, I just simply enable auto-converge, and the live migration complete successfully with it's help. Proposed change =============== A new option auto-converge will be added in migrate_server API. And it will be passed to libvirt/driver _live_migration_operation, then libvirt will enable the auto-converge capability of hypervisor. For low version libvirt which does not support auto-converge, the operator still want auto-converge to help to complete live migration successfully when VM with heavy workloads. So an extended auto-converge command will be supported by libvirt qemu-monitor-command. Alternatives ------------ Alternative is not doing this and let operator enable auto-converge manually through hypervisor. Add a new auto-converge action API to enable hypervisor auto-converge capability. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- A new flag auto_converge will be added as optional, the json-schema as below:: { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'os-migrateLive': { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'block_migration': parameter_types.boolean, 'disk_over_commit': parameter_types.boolean, 'auto_converge': parameter_types.boolean, 'host': host }, 'additionalProperties': False, }, }, 'required': ['os-migrateLive'], 'additionalProperties': False, } This change need new microversion. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User need specify auto-converge true explicitly when they want hypervisor to throttle CPU intelligently. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ShaoHe Feng <shaohe.feng@intel.com> Other contributors: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com> Work Items ---------- * A new option auto-converge is added in migrate_server API. * An extended auto-converge command through libvirt qemu-monitor-command is added. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittest and funtional tests in Nova Documentation Impact ==================== Doc the API change in the API Reference: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html References ========== None History ======= Mitaka: Introduced
