commit_message:
Adds post-copy live migration support to Nova

At present, only pre-copy live migration is supported at OpenStack.
This spec proposes adding support for post-copy live migration at
OpenStack, including the possibility of lively switch from pre-copy
to post-copy for ongoing live migrations.

Change-Id: I75add03c331204fcd9b48d37c52427829eb17339
Signed-off-by: Luis Tomas <luis5tb@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/09/301509/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Enable post-copy live migration option ========================================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/post-copy At present, only pre-copy live migration is supported at OpenStack. This spec proposes adding support for post-copy live migration at OpenStack, including the possibility of lively switch from pre-copy to post-copy for ongoing live migrations. Problem description =================== Currently only pre-copy live migration is supported at OpenStack, which is not able to live migrate those VMs whose applications are dirting memory faster than the available network bandwidth between source and destination hosts. As a result, if the admin needs to complete the migration, it needs to either cancel the migration and migrate the VM as a cold migration or set a time out for it, so that after that time the VM is paused and migrated. In both cases, the migration is not live anymore and the downtime may be unacceptable. In addition to that, pre-copy live migration may need to re-send several times the same memory page if is being dirtied during the migration process, being that network and application dependent, and hence difficulting predictions about total migration duration, as well as increasing the network traffic. Use Cases --------- An OpenStack cloud operator may require the ability to live migrate VMs regardless of the application they are running or what is the available network bandwidth. This is possible by using post-copy live migration instead of pre-copy live migration, and will provide the next advantages: * Possibility of live migrate VMs when the VMs are dirting memory faster than the available network bandwidth, be it due to a low network bandwdidth or due to the VMs writing memory exhaustively. * Upper limit into the amount of memory that need to be sent to the destination host, and therefore minimizing the stress on the network, specially if several VMs need to be concurrently migrated. * More easyly predictable migration times. Proposed change =============== An extension to the live migration API with a post-copy flag to start VMs live migrations in a post-copy ready mode, meaning that live migrations can be switched to post-copy mode at any point in time during the migration time, either manually or automatically. This will follow exactly the same flow as normal pre-copy migrations, but ensuring the proper libvirt flags are used. In order to implement this change, the live migration code in method `_migrate_live` of `nova/api/openstack/compute/migrate_server.py` will be modified to acept the new flag. Additionally, a new API method to switch an ongoing pre-copy live migration to post-copy mode will be created. This will make asynchronous RPC call to compute node (the source host) to switch the migration mode to post-copy through libvirt. In order to implement this change, the live migration code in nova/api/openstack/compute/server_migrations.py will be extended to include the new API. This will be implemented in a similar way to the current `_force_complete method`, where a `live_migrate_switch_to_postcopy` method will be called. This needs to firstly check if there is an ongoing migration and that it has not being already switched to post-copy mode. Note the policy.json file will be updated to define the `live_migrate_switch_to_postcopy` as accessible to cloud admin users only. Then, if the API server determines that the operation can proceed it will send an async message to the compute manager, which in turn will invoke a method on the driver to switch the ongoing migration to post-copy mode. If the driver is unable to perform this operation a new exception called `SwitchPostCopyMigrationNotSupported` will be returned. Otherwise, the libvirt driver will obtain the domain object for the target instance and invoke the post-copy switch action. If there is no job active an error will be returned. This could occur if the instance migration has recently finished, or has completed the libvirt migration and is executing the post migration phase. In these cases an exception will be returned to the compute manager to indicate that the operation was unsuccessful. Note these changes also entail that, if a VM live migration has already been switched to post-copy mode, any cancelation should be declined as non of the hosts have a complete version of the VM. Finally, Novaclient will need to be modified to enable the use of the post-copy flag for live migrations, as well as to include the new API method for switching to post-copy mode. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is using cold migration to migrate VMs that write memory at high rates or when the available network bandwidth is low. Another alternative is hardcode the post-copy libvirt flags into the nova.conf file, however this will remove the possibility of choosing between pre-copy and postcopy, and will have the next impact: * Postcopy migrations cannot be aborted, therefore, if the flag is hardcoded, no migrations could be stopped. * Postcopy migrations may loss the VM if a failure happend during the migration process as none of the hosts has yet a complete version of the VM. Therefore, for migratable VMs could be still interesting to use pre-copy migrations, or just change to post-copy after some time if the migration cannot finish. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- To be extended: * Enable post-copy live migration at live-migrate by including an extra parameter: `POST /servers/{id}/migrations/{id}/action` Body:: { "os-migrateLive":{ "host": "01c0...", "block_migration": false, "disk_over_commit": false, "post_copy": false } } Neither the normal response codes nor the error response codes would change. To be added: * Switch the ongoing live-migration to post-copy mode: `POST /servers/{id}/migrations/{id}/action` Body:: { "switch_postcopy": null } Normal http response code: `202 Accepted` No response body is needed Expected error http response code: `400 Bad Request` - the instance state is invalid for forcing live migration to complete, i.e., the task state is not 'migrating' or the migration is not post-copy enabled. Expected error http response code: `403 Forbidden` - Policy violation if the caller is not granted access to 'os_compute_api:servers:migrations:switch_postcopy' in policy.json Expected error http response code: `404 Not Found` - the instance does not exist Because this is async call there might be an error that will not be exposed through API. Such error will be logged by compute service. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- Emit notification messages indicating the switch to post-copy mode. Other end user impact --------------------- The live migration python-novaclient command will be extended to include the postcopy migration flag and its optional extra parameters, e.g.: `nova live-migration [--postcopy] <instance>` A new python-novaclient command will be available to manually switch to postcopy mode, e.g.: `nova switch-postcopy <instance>` Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- The post-copy libvirt flags should be included at either nova.conf and/or the libvirt driver file and will be used for post-copy enabled migrations: * VIR_MIGRATE_POSTCOPY Note that even if this libvirt flag is included, that does not mean the VM is migrated in post-copy mode, only that it is ready to be switched to post-copy when needed. Even if post-copy migrations are not used at all, that flag will not affect pre-copy VM live migrations but will have some overhead. Therefore it is better to have different set of flags for pre- and post-copy migrations. This also means that if a migration was not started with the post-copy flag, it cannot be switched to post-copy mode later on. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Luis Toms (email: luis5tb@gmail.com) Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * python-novaclient `nova live-migration [--post-copy]` * python-novaclient `nova switch-postcopy` * Switch live migration to postcopy API operation * Extend live migration API operation to include post-copy flag * Starting migration in post-copy ready status for libvirt hypervisor * Switching migration to post-copy mode for libvirt hypervisor * Disable functions not available in post-copy mode, such as abort migrations * Only allow post-copy for libvirt (from libvirt version 1.3.3) Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Scenarios to be tested: * Switch from pre-copy to post-copy live migration * Abort post-copy live migration, i.e., check it is not allowed How to test them: * Unit tests, functional API tests. * Tempest tests: extend live migration tempest by using an instance with high memory activity so that it cannot be migrated with pre-copy live migration. A test will be implemented to test the switch to post-copy. Documentation Impact ==================== New API needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html * nova.compute.api documentation http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.compute.api.html References ========== History =======

commit_message:
instance.create notifications should emit with scheduler hints

One use case would be Heat's stack_scheduler_hints. Currently, when the
Heat configuration stack_scheduler_hints is set to True, Heat's
scheduler hints are sent to Nova. However, Nova notifications don't have
this information available.

An enhancement for Nova Notifications would be to include in the
notification scheduler hint information that is passed into Nova. This
could be done by adding 'scheduler_hints' to the create notifications'
payload.

Change-Id: I2088e9a14bc73b7d3deeb2e35e474830cc9063ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/69/312169/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Nova Create Notification to include Scheduler Hints =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-create-notification-scheduler-hints Creating Nova Servers should emit create notifications that contain scheduelr hints. Problem Description =================== Currently, nova.instance.create notifications do not contain scheduler hints. Scheduler hints are passed into nova-scheduler to help filter appropriate hosts for an instance. There are tools that benefit in consuming certain scheduler hints (e.g. Heat Stack information) from nova.instance.create notifications. Use Cases --------- As a developer, I want to create a tool that consumes notifications and takes scheduler hints specified for an instance. Proposed Change =============== This spec intends to modify the compute.instance.create.* by adding a new field to its payload, called 'scheduler_hints'. This new field will contain all the scheduler hints used for this instance. During the emission of create notifications, the 'scheduler_hints' field of filter_properties will be added. compute.instance.create.* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ There will be a class InstanceCreatePayload that holds specific fields for compute.instance.create.* notifications:: @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register_if(False) class InstanceCreatePayload(InstancePayload): VERSION = '1.1' fields = { 'scheduler_hints': fields.DictOfListOfStringsField(nullable=True) } def __init__(self, instance): super(InstanceCreatePayload, self).__init__(instance) nova.compute.manage._build_and_run_instance ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In the method nova.manager._build_and_run_instance, the extra_usage_info arguments for calls to nova.manager._notify_about_instance_usage will contain filter_properties.get('scheduler_hints'). Here is an example of the change to compute.instance.create.start to include the scheduler_hints:: def _build_and_run_instance(self, context, instance, image, injected_files, admin_password, requested_networks, security_groups, block_device_mapping, node, limits, filter_properties): image_name = image.get('name') scheduler_hints = filter_properties.get('scheduler_hints') self._notify_about_instance_usage(context, instance, 'create.start', extra_usage_info={ 'image_name': image_name 'scheduler_hints': scheduler_hints}) # ...rest of the code Alternatives ------------ The field can be added to a different base class such as InstancePayload, but the current use case only needs to consume from compute.instance.create.* notifications Data model impact ----------------- The versioned notification for compute.instance.create will contain a new field called scheduler_hints REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- The compute.instance.create notifications will also have scheduler hints used. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance impact ------------------ The compute.instance.create notifications will contain an additional field. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact --------------- Developers would be able to write tools and features that can consume scheduler hints from compute.instance.create notifications Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Julian Sy - js802v@att.com <syjulian> Other contributors: * Andy Hsiang - yh418t@att.com <xenogears> * Bass Toure - mt104b@att.com <BassT> Work Items ---------- * Create or modify definition of InstanceCreatePayload to have new scheduler_hints field. * Modify calls to notify compute.instance.create.* to include scheduler hints. Dependencies ============ Currently there is a spec [1] that proposes to transform the notifications to a versioned format. The spec uses the compute.instance.update and compute.instance.delete as examples. The added field to the notifications will depend on the new versioned format of compute.instance.create notifications. A patch [2] is already in progress for transforming compute.instance.create notifications among other notifications. Testing ======= There will be unit tests to check if the notification include the new field. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/286675/ [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279416/

subject: Hide Exclusive Availability zones
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 06:31:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/824e36c56c81f24e805e8998dfc4180a3990fc11', 'message': 'Hide Exclusive Availability zones

The blueprint propose some modification to the availability list API to hide
exclusive availability zones, if filter AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation
is enabled.

commit_message:
Hide Exclusive Availability zones

The blueprint propose some modification to the availability list API to hide
exclusive availability zones, if filter AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation
is enabled.

Change-Id: I74f017f61527b0ed89eaf0bb0252bbb591b8641d
Blueprint: hide-exclusive-availability-zone
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/64/333764/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================= Hide Exclusive Availability zones ================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/hide-exclusive-availability-zone The blueprint propose some modification to the availability list API to hide exclusive availability zones, if scheduler filter AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation is enabled. Problem description =================== At Grizzly we got a new scheduler filter: AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation.[1] If adding metadata `filter_tenant_id=<TENANT_ID>` to an aggregate, the aggregate will become exclusive for this tenant(s). Currenty, only admin can get the isolation information through aggregate-list API. As an end user, I know nothing about aggregate, I can only see availability zone, but even all aggregates in an availability zone were marked as dedicated, I can still see this availability zone, but I got a ERROR vm at finally, because there is no valid host for me. Use Cases --------- As an operator, I only get the availability zones that available to me, so I will not create VMs on some dedicated availability zone by accidently. Proposed change =============== First of all, if AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation is not enabled, nothing new happened. If enabled, availability zone list API will only return two kinds of aggregates: 1. Aggregate(s) that have no metadata key `filter_tenant_id`. 2. Aggregate(s) that have metadata key `filter_tenant_id` and value is user's tenant id. Below two query should be implemented by some sqlalchemy filter method rather than python list filtering. Alternatives ------------ The alternative would get all aggregate in python object, then filter them one by one. This is the worst way I can think out. Data model impact ----------------- No data model need to change, all aggregate metadatas is already there. REST API impact --------------- Below two API will return only the availability zone that available to user. * GET /os-availability-zone * GET /os-availability-zone/detail Security impact --------------- This blueprint will harden the security, because some exclusive availability may be classified, and should not be seen by other users. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Tiantian Gao <gtt116@gmail.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add new method in aggregate objects to filter out dedicated aggregates. * Make availability zone list API return valid availability zones, increase microversion of API. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Add requires unit test for the new aggregate object method. * Add new tempest testcase for the API modification. Documentation Impact ==================== * The Operations guide need to be updated about this feature. References ========== [1] Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/multi-tenancy-aggregates History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Add direct download feature for rbd glance backend

This blueprint aims to support for the direct download feature
for "rbd glance image backend" when nova boot.
Supporting for direct downloads of glance locations is
already added by plug-in modules.
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37817)
And this feature only can support file not rbd images.

Added new rbd download scheme for Nova.
With that change Nova can download RBD images directly from
Ceph using 'rbd export' command not involving rather
slow download by HTTP from Glance server.

Instead of copying through glance node, nova-compute service
can directly download image from ceph to
compute node using rbd direct url.

the workflow is simple as follows:

    1. Create an image with ceph glance backend.
    2. nova boot with the image created above.

Configuration options for nova.conf should be added as below.
 : allowed_direct_url_schemes = [file,rbd]

Change-Id: I88ac1c772a56abb284d77319e07c8bf6c294b4da
Implements: blueprint direct-download-for-rbd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/81/308481/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Add direct download feature for rbd glance backend =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/direct-download-for-rbd This blueprint aims to support for the direct download feature for "rbd glance image backend" when nova boot. Problem description =================== Supporting for direct downloads of glance locations is already added by plug-in modules.[1] And this feature only can support file not rbd images. Added new rbd download scheme for Nova. With that change Nova can download RBD images directly from Ceph using 'rbd export' command not involving rather slow download by HTTP from Glance server. Use Cases --------- No changes to a typical end-user's request for "nova boot". Nova service just uses rbd direct_url for download glance images directly to boot vm. Proposed change =============== Instead of copying through glance node, nova-compute service can directly download image from ceph to compute node. the workflow is simple as follows: 1. Create an image with ceph glance backend. 2. nova boot with the image created above. Failures will be reported in the form of stack traces in the nova compute logs. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- Glance will need to be configured with direct_url support enabled in order for Nova to determine what and where to export the image from, depending on system configurations, this could leak backend credentials [2]. Devstack has already been updated to switch behaviors when Ceph support is requested [3]. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: raymon-ha Other contributors: cosmos0703,daeseong.kim,jangpro2,jihyun-song0829 Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ You need a newer version of glance as direct URL was added. Testing ======= The unit tests will of course cover the new code. As direct download is enabled automatically, there is no need to change the tempest tests. And make sure that when configured conrrectly direct url is used. Documentation Impact ==================== Some configuration options for nova.conf should be added as below. 1. allowed_direct_url_schemes = [file,rbd] 2. Timeout value used when connecting ceph cluster : rados_connect_timeout = 0 References ========== [1] Add plug-in modules for direct downloads of glance locations: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37817/ [2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/880910 [3] https://review.openstack.org/206039 History ======= None

commit_message:
Expand Instance Actions Coverage

We propose to expand the range of instance actions that are covered
by the os-instance-actions API.

blueprint expand-instance-actions-coverage

Change-Id: I86b36040fa43d2ae7b10283f489491b2b2525d31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/43/256743/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Expand Instance Actions Coverage ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/expand-instance-actions-coverage We propose to expand the range of instance actions that are covered by the os-instance-actions API. Problem description =================== Currently, Nova exposes 22 server actions [NC0]_ through the os-instance-actions API [OS1]_. These are not, however, an exhaustive set of server actions. We propose to expand this set of server actions to include other actions of interest. Use Cases --------- As a User, I want to be able to use the os-instance-actions API to get information about all actions associated with my server. Proposed change =============== We propose to add coverage of the following server actions: * snapshot * backup * shelve offload * lock * unlock The above actions (plus the 22 mentioned earlier) comprise the total listed under the heading "Server actions" in the Compute API Guide [NC1]_. Alternatives ------------ Do nothing and let users make inferences from an instance's status and task_state about the situation of the instance with respect to the actions it is undertaking. Data model impact ----------------- None. This change would expand the range of actions covered using the existing instance-actions framework. REST API impact --------------- The 'action' field of the os-instance-actions API response will contain additional values. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ No significant performance impact is anticipated. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: toan-nguyen Other contributors: brian-rosmaita Work Items ---------- #. Add instance-actions coverage for the "new" actions. Dependencies ============ It's not strictly speaking a dependency, but this work should follow implementation of the "Consistent Success Reporting" blueprint [GR1]_. Testing ======= Appropriate tests would be added to the currently existing os-instance-actions tests. Documentation Impact ==================== The os-instance-actions API documentation currently does not explicitly list the possible values of the "action" field in the response. So either there will be no change (if we want to preserve the status quo) or the docs can be updated to include a complete list of values. References ========== .. [GR1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/248248/ .. [NC0] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2e46e453d8fe377f3823df1572d9fc08f03f0964/nova/compute/instance_actions.py .. [NC1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/20db45da9945e4c8125619df1fee69cf6663f1c0/api-guide/source/server_concepts.rst .. [OS1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#os-instance-actions-v2.1 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Proposal for standardizing hardware NIC capabilities

Change-Id: I55d2c1d7d5d525b73b64a4d4426e41438233ada4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/41/341341/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Standardize NIC and Networking capabilities =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/standardize-nic-capabilities We propose to standardize some of the common networking capabilities supported by NIC and vSwitch and represent these capabilities as specified in nova capability standardization spec [nova- standardize-capabilities-ref] to enable nova scheduler to use these host capabilities while scheduling virtual servers. Problem description =================== Nova scheduler selects a host that satisfies all the constraints specified by the user, while scheduling a server. Default nova scheduler (filter scheduler) has a set of filters which implement hard constraints with respect to hardware capabilities like number of vCPUs, available RAM and free disk space as python modules. Hardware capability constraints outside of these standard filters are applied through host aggregate meta-data. Vendor specific capabilities are tagged to each host or a set of hosts (host aggregates) and host aggregate filter will match these host specific tags with user specified required tags to schedule a given server. User specifies required tags as extra specs in user request. There is no standardized way to expose these capabilities and its up to the administrator to define these tags and same functionality can end up having different tags across different vendor devices. There is an ongoing effortsecent spec [nova- standardize-capabilities-ref] proposed a mechanism to standardize the host capabilities. And this spec uses this mechanism to standardize some of the most common NICs and vSwitch capabilities. In open stack environment virtual switch (vSwitch) implementation depends on hypervisor technology being used for virtualization. Openvswitch [openvswitch-ref] is one of the virtual switches that are used with KVM/QEMU hypervisor, similarly vSphere Distributed Switch [dvSwitch-ref] for VMWare vSphere hypervisor and Hyper-V vSwitch [hyperv-vswitch-ref] with Microsoft Hyper-V. Proposed Changes ================ We propose to standardize the following NIC and vSwitch capabilities. Standardizing capabilities involve in defining new `nova.objects.fields.Enum` classes with each one representing on standard capability. Use Case 1: ----------- While scheduling a virtual server, a user would desire to pick the compute host that supports a capability such as port mirroring with a specified granularity on vSwitch or NIC level. Hence we represent the capability to have values for NIC and/or vSwitch. This also address the case when the user would desire to pick a compute node where both the vSwitch and the NIC need to support a feature. For example, for performance reasons the user might want to use the Generic Segmentation Offload (also known as TCP Segmentation Offload) to off load TCP segmentation in the NIC. For this feature obviously the NIC should support it, but also the vSwitch should not do the segmentation in software, and hand over large segment correctly (i.e. with the right flags in the NIC descriptors set). This use case refers to TSO, but same principle applies to any stateless offloads. The actual implementation of this would be through a JSON filter or equivalent approach and will be addressed in a separate spec. Use Case 2: ---------- Additionally, while scheduling a virtual server, a user would desire to pick a host based on a capability such as port mirroring and not necessarily be prescriptive about the fact that the capability is present NIC or vSwitch. Hence the HW/SW component is modeled as a leaf node. The user will also be returned the HW/SW component which was selected. The suggested data model supports use cases 1 and 2 as described above. Data model impact ================== Open stack capability group will be modified to include network capability group. class CapabilityGroup(Enum): """Groups of capabilities.""" SYSTEM = 'sys' HARDWARE = 'hw' HYPERVISOR = 'virt' NETWORK = net class HwNicCapabilityGroup(CapabilityGroup):  Group for NIC capabilities. PREFIX = CapabilityGroup.HARDWARE + :nic PORTSPEED = portspeed CRYPTO_ACCLN = crypto_accln COMPRESSION_ACCLN = compression_accln STATELESS_PROTOCOL_OFFLOADS = stateless_protocol_offloads STATELESS_TUNNEL_PROTOCOL_OFFLOADS = stateless_tunnel_protocol_offloads MULTIQUEUE = multiqueue VMDQ = vmdq SRIOV = sriov PROGRAMMABLE_PIPELINE = programmable_pipeline DCB = dcb class NetworkCapabilityGroup(CapabilityGroup): Group for Network capabilities supported either by NIC or vSwitch PREFIX = CapabilityGroup.NETWORK MIRRORING = mirroring L2L3Tunnel = l2l3tunnel SERVICE_CHAINING = service_chaining class Capability (Enum): pass Mirroring (net:mirroring) ------------------------- Mirroring feature enables users to perform intrusion detection, network performance management, traffic analysis, user monitoring etc. by sending a copy of a packet received or transmitted on a switch/server port to a monitor port where network analyzer is attached. Monitor port could be either in same device (switch/server) or in aa different network device connected through the network. In a virtualized environment, mirroring may be used to monitor the traffic on a virtual machine port. In a virtualized environment with KVM hypervisor, all the virtual machines instantiated on a compute node will have attachment port on Openvswitch (vSwitch for KVM) and user can enable port mirroring on these ports if needed. Besides the openvswitch, mirroring can be enabled on compute node NICs as well since some of the NICs also support port mirroring. Mirroring can be enabled either on all the traffic through a port or traffic that belongs to a specific network or very specific application traffic. Granularity of the traffic that is being mirrored is configurable. Here is the list of mirroring granularity levels. Mirroring group (MirroringGroup) represents these granularities while enabling mirroring. Mirroring can be enabled either on OVS [mirroring-ovs-ref] running within hypervisor or on the NIC level. While instantiating a server, user may have a specific requirement that mirroring capability should be enabled on NIC or on OVS. Or user may be OK as long as mirroring is enabled either on NIC or OVS. Mirroring has two modes: SPAN or RSPAN. SPAN mirroring represents the case when the monitoring port is local and RSPAN mirroring represents the case when the monitoring port is remote [span-rspan-ref]. For RSPAN, there has to be tunnel to stream the mirroring traffic between the source and destination. class MirroringGroup(NetworkCapabilityGroup): Group for mirroring capabilities, representing level of granularity. PREFIX = super(self).PREFIX + : + super(self).MIRRORING PORT_MIRRORING = port NETWORK_MIRRORING = net FLOW_MIRRORING = flow class Mirroring(Capability): """Mirroring Capabilities""" PREFIX = MirroringGroup.PREFIX + ':' MIRROR_PORT_OVS = self.PREFIX + MirroringGroup.PORT_MIRRORING + :ovs MIRROR_PORT_NIC = self.PREFIX + MirroringGroup.PORT_MIRRORING + :nic MIRROR_NET_OVS = self.PREFIX + MirroringGroup.NETWORK_MIRRORING + :ovs MIRROR_NET_NIC self.PREFIX + MirroringGroup.NETWORK_MIRRORING + :nic MIRROR_FLOW_OVS = self.PREFIX + MirroringGroup.FLOW_MIRRORING + :ovs MIRROR_FLOW_NIC = self.PREFIX + MirroringGroup.FLOW_MIRRORING + :nic L2/L3 Tunnels (net:l2l3tunnel) ------------------------------- L2/L3 tunnels are configured to extend a network over heterogeneous networks either be it internet or private enterprise networks. Over the years multiple tunneling protocols have evolved solving different use cases and different data packet forwarding technologies. This capability group encompasses all such tunneling encapsulation protocols. class L2L3TunnelGroup (NetworkCapabilityGroup):  L2/L3 tunnel group encompasses multiple tunnel types PREFIX = NetworkCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + NetworkCapabilityGroup.L2L3Tunnel VXLAN = self.PREFIX + :vxlan # [vxlan-ref] GRE = self.PREFIX + :gre # [gre-ref] NVGRE = self.PREFIX + :nvgre # [nvgre-ref] MPLS = self.PREFIX + :mpls # [mpls-ref] VXLANGPE = self.PREFIX + :vxlangpe # [vxlangpe-ref] GENEVE = self.PREFIX + :geneve # [geneve-ref] class L2L3TunnelOvs(Capability): POSTFIX = :ovs VXLAN_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.VXLAN + self.POSTFIX GRE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.GRE + self.POSTFIX NVGRE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.NVGRE + self.POSTFIX MPLS_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.MPLS + self.POSTFIX VXLAN_GPE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.VXLANGPE + self.POSTFIX GENEVE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.GENEVE + self.POSTFIX class L2L3TunnelNic(Capability): POSTFIX = :nic VXLAN_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.VXLAN + self.POSTFIX GRE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.GRE + self.POSTFIX NVGRE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.NVGRE + self.POSTFIX MPLS_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.MPLS + self.POSTFIX VXLAN_GPE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.VXLANGPE + self.POSTFIX GENEVE_TUNNEL = L2L3TunnelGroup.GENEVE + self.POSTFIX Physical Port Speed/Bandwidth (hw:nic:portspeed) ------------------------------------------------ All the network interfaces in a physical server will have a specific port speed either configured or auto-negotiated. Network interface speed corresponds to bandwidth it supports. In a typical virtualized environment, all the ports configured on Virtual Machine are attached to vSwitch and theyre not directly mapped to a physical interface. East-west traffic between the Virtual Machines may be switched within vSwitch itself and hence may not even traverse through physical interface. But, in network deployments where hardware acceleration is enabled by SR-IOV, each virtual server interface is mapped directly to a logical function(logical segment of a device). In SR-IOV deployments, even the east-west traffic between the virtual servers within the same physical host will traverse the physical NIC. In these kind of deployments, users will be interested to use NIC bandwidth while scheduling a Virtual Server. The following capability group represents all the network interface speeds. class Portspeed (Capability): PREFIX = HwNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HwNicCapabilityGroup.PORTSPEED PORT_BW_10_MB = self.PREFIX + :10mb PORT_BW_100_MB = self.PREFIX + :100mb PORT_BW_1_GB = self.PREFIX + :1gb PORT_BW_10_GB = self.PREFIX + :10gb PORT_BW_25_GB = self.PREFIX + :25gb PORT_BW_40_GB = self.PREFIX + :40gb PORT_BW_100_GB = self.PREFIX + :100gb PORT_BW_200_GB = self.PREFIX + :200gb Cryptographic HW Acceleration (hw:nic:crypto_accln) --------------------------------------------------- Cryptographic protocols such as IPSEC, SSL etc. often have better performance with HW implementations as compared to equivalent SW implementations. Several NICs (special purpose and general) provide HW acceleration capability for cryptographic functions [crypto-accln-ref1] [crypto-accln-ref2]. A relevant NFV use case is an IPSEC tunnel from an enterprise branch office. class CryptoAccln (Capability): PREFIX = HwNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HwNicCapabilityGroup.CRYPTO_ACCLN SYMM_CRYPTO_IPSEC = self.PREFIX + :symm_ipsec SYMM_CRYPTO_SSL = self.PREFIX + :symm_ssl SYMM_CRYPTO_TLS = self.PREFIX + :symm_tls ASYMM_CRYPTO_DIFFIEH = self.PREFIX + :asymm_diffieh ASYMM_CRYPTO_RSA = self.PREFIX + :asymm_rsa SYMM_CRYPTO_ELLIPTICC = self.PREFIX + :symm_elipticc Compression HW Acceleration (hw:nic:compression_accln) ------------------------------------------------------ Compression algorithms such as LZS and Deflate can be accelerated through HW. Several NICs (special purpose and general) provide HW acceleration capability for compression functions [compression-accln-ref]. A relevant NFV use case is WAN acceleration. class CompressionAccln (Capability): PREFIX = HwNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX +:+ HwNicCapabilityGroup.COMPRESSION_ACCLN COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM_LZS = self.PREFIX + :algo_lzs COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM_DEFLATE = self.PREFIX + :algo_deflate Stateless protocol offloads (hw:nic:stateless_protocol_offloads) ---------------------------------------------------------------- TCP/UDP/SCTP checksums, Layer 2 CRC, Large send [large-send-ref], Large receive [large-recv-ref], Receive side scaling for TCP traffic [recv-side-scaling-ref], based on hash-based filters, can be offloaded to the NIC for overall performance improvement. For specific non-hash-based filters, please refer to [directed-workloads-ref] and [flow-director-ref]. Similarly, the stateless protocol offloads, vlan tagging and q-in-q [q-in-q-ref] can be offloaded in the NIC so that no CPU cycles are spent on dealing with this type of tagging provided the NIC descriptors can be set correctly, and the software stack to avoid doing the tag insertion/extraction. class StatelessProtocolOffloads (Capability): PREFIX = HwNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HwNicCapabilityGroup.STATELESS_PROTOCOL_OFFLOADS STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_TCP_CHECKSUM = self.PREFIX + :tcp_checksum STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_UDP_CHECKSUM = self.PREFIX + :udp_checksum STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_SCTP_CHECKSUM = self.PREFIX + :sctp_checksum STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_LARGE_SEND = self.PREFIX + :large_send STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_LARGE_RECV = self.PREFIX + :large_recv STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_RECV_SIDE_SCALING = self.PREFIX +:recv_side_scaling STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_LAYER2_CRC = self.PREFIX + :layer2_crc STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_FLOW_DIRECTOR_FILTER = self.PREFIX + :flow-director-filter STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_VLAN_TAG = self.PREFIX + :vlan_tag STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_QINQ = self.PREFIX + :qinq Stateless tunnel protocol offloads (hw:nic:stateless_tunnel_protocol_offloads) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The goal of stateless tunnel protocol offloads is to make sure that the above described stateless protocol offloads are supported for tunnel protocols encapsulated packet [stateless-tunnel-offload-ref]. Today there have been NICs identified to be able to handle stateless offloads for VXLAN, GRE and GENEVE. Class StatelessTunnelProtocoOffloads (Capability): PREFIX = HwNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + ':' HwNicCapabilityGroup.STATELESS_TUNNEL_PROTOCOL_OFFLOADS STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_VXLAN = self.PREFIX + :vxlan STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_GRE = self.PREFIX + :gre STATELESS_PROTO_OFFLOAD_GENEVE = self.PREFIX + :geneve Service chaining (net:service_chaining) --------------------------------------- Service chaining is the process of interconnection of various network functions (physical or virtual) such as firewall, WAN acceleration etc. to offer an end-to-end service to a customer. It is also known as a VNF forwarding graph in ETSI NFV terminology [etsi-nfv-use-cases-ref]. NSH header [ietf-nsh-ref] facilitates carrying of shared metadata between network devices and network functions, and between network functions. Class ServiceChainingOvs (Capability): PREFIX = NetworkCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + :+ NetworkCapabilityGroup.SERVICE_CHAINING POSTFIX = :ovs SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_BYPASS_OVS = self.PREFIX + :nsh_bypass + self.POSTFIX SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_PROCESS_OVS = self.PREFIX + :nsh_process + self.POSTFIX SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_ADD_BASE_OVS = self.PREFIX + :nsh_add_base + self.POSTFIX SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_ADD_OPTIONAL_OVS = self.PREFIX + :nsh_add_optional + self.POSTFIX Class ServiceChainingNic (Capability): PREFIX = NetworkCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + NetworkCapabilityGroup.service_chaining POSTFIX = :nic SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_BYPASS_NIC = self.PREFIX + :nsh_bypass + self.POSTFIX SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_PROCESS_NIC = self.PREFIX + :nsh_process + self.POSTFIX SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_ADD_BASE_NIC = self.PREFIX + :nsh_add_base + self.POSTFIX SERVICE_CHAINING_NSH_ADD_OPTIONAL_NIC = self.PREFIX + :nsh_add_optional + self.POSTFIX Multiqueue (hw:nic:multiqueue) ------------------------------ Multiqueue allows to segment a physical NIC port to logical queues so that a multicore system can assign queues to cores for parallel packet processing through IRQ affinity [multiqueue-ref]. Then, through queue assignment technologies (based on RSS 5 tuple hashing or more advanced techniques such as flow-director perfect filters) the NIC can spread packets across these queues  these are discussed in the stateless protocol offload section. Class Multiqueue (Capability): PREFIX = HWNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HWNicCapabilityGroup.MULTIQUEUE MULTIQUEUE = self.PREFIX Vmdq (hw:nic:vmdq) ------------------- Virtual Machine Device Queues (VMDq) is a technology in the HW NIC that offloads network I/O management burden from the hypervisor [vmdq-ref]. Multiple queues and sorting intelligence in the HW NIC support enhanced network traffic flow in the virtual environment, freeing processor cycles for application work. As data packets arrive at the network adapter, a Layer 2 classifier/sorter in the network controller sorts and determines which VM each packet is destined for based on MAC addresses and VLAN tags. It then places the packet in a receive queue assigned to that VM. The hypervisors switch merely routes the packets to the respective VM instead of performing the heavy lifting work of sorting data. Thus, VMDq improves platform efficiency for handling receive-side network I/O and increases CPU utilization for application processing. Class Vmdq (Capability): PREFIX = HWNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HWNicCapabilityGroup.vmdq VMDQ = self.PREFIX SR-IOV (hw:nic:sriov) ---------------------- The goal of the PCI-SIG SR-IOV specification is to standardize on a way of bypassing the hypervisor involvement in data movement by providing independent memory space, interrupts, and DMA streams for each virtual machine. SR-IOV architecture is designed to allow a device to support multiple Virtual Functions (VFs) and much attention was placed on minimizing the hardware cost of each additional function. SR-IOV-capable devices provide configurable numbers of independent VFs, each with its own PCI Configuration space. The hypervisor assigns one or more VF to a virtual machine. Memory Translation technologies provide hardware assisted techniques to allow direct DMA transfers to and from the VM, thus bypassing the software switch in the hypervisor [sr-iov-ref]. The SR-IOV companion reference [sr-iov-companion-ref] elaborates on anti-spoofing. The SR-IOV QoS reference [sr-iov-qos-ref] elaborates on rate-limiting and other QoS functionality. The SR-IOV promiscuous reference [sr-iov-promicuous-ref] elaborates on promiscuous mode support in Intel adapters. Class SrIov (Capability): PREFIX = HWNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HWNicCapabilityGroup.SRIOV SRIOV_VF_QOS_TX_RATE_LIMIT = self.PREFIX + :vf_qos_tx_rate_limit SRIOV_VF_QOS_RX_RATE_LIMIT = self.PREFIX + :vf_qos_rx_rate_limit SRIOV_VF_QOS_MULTI_QUEUE_PER_VF = self.PREFIX + :vf_qos_multi_queue_per_vf SR-IOV_CONFIGURABLE_MTU = self.PREFIX + :configurable_mtu SR-IOV_ANTI-SPOOFING_MAC = self.PREFIX + :antispoofing_mac SR-IOV_ANTI-SPOOFING_VLAN = self.PREFIX + :antispoofing_vlan SR-IOV_UNKNOWN_UNICAST = self.PREFIX + :unknown_unicast Programmable_pipeline (hw:nic:programmable_pipeline) ---------------------------------------------------- A more generic way to think of NPUs and FPGAs is a programmable pipeline. As an example, [programmable-nic-ref] has an FPGA which can be programmed to deliver functions such as DoS attack prevention, IPSEC encryption etc. Class ProgrammablePipeline (Capability): PREFIX = HWNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HWNicCapabilityGroup.PROGRAMMABLE_PIPELINE PROGRAMMABLE_PIPELINE = self.PREFIX Datacenter Bridging (hw:nic:dcb) -------------------------------- Data center bridging [dcb-ref] encompasses a collection of technologies targeted to enhance Ethernet reliability which is originally designed to be best-effort network. New data center architectures evolved to have I/O consolidation and enhanced Ethernet features. I/O consolidation technology like FCoE allows Fibre channel communication over Ethernet, which leads to dramatic reduction in number of network adapters, low power consumption and lower TCO. Fibre channel traffic forces Ethernet to be loss less and data center bridging technologies enhance Ethernet to be loss less. IEEE 802.1Qbb Priority Flow Control (PFC) extends the granularity of PAUSE frame to accommodate the priority queues (.1p). Using PFC, link is divided into eight virtual queues and PAUSE can be applied to each individual queue. With the capability to enable PAUSE on a per-user-priority basis, a lossless lane for Fibre Channel can be created while retaining packet-drop congestion management for IP traffic. This mechanism allows storage traffic to share the same link as non-storage traffic. IEEE 802.1Qaz Enhanced Transmission Selection (ETS) is used to assign traffic to a particular virtual lane using IEEE 802.1p class of service (CoS) values to identify which virtual lane traffic belongs to. Using PFC and ETS allows administrators to allocate resources, including buffers and queues, based on user priority, which results in a higher level of service for critical traffic where congestion has the greatest effect. IEEE 802.1Qau Quantized Congestion Notification (QCN) enhances the granularity of Congestion Notification Messages transmission from a switch. Switches always monitors their output queues and whenever an output queue reaches threshold (low/high thresholds), they send CNM packets back to the sender (one for every n packets, where n depends on output queue threshold). Each CNM packet contains enough information like destination address, priority etc. so that the sender reduce the transmission rate of that specific traffic. Class DataCenterBridging (Capability): PREFIX = HwNicCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + HwNicCapabilityGroup.DCB DCB_PFC = DataCenterBridging.PREFIX + :pfc DCB_ETS = DataCenterBridging.PREFIX + :ets DCB_QCN = DataCenterBridging.PREFIX + :qcn OpenFlow TTP (net:openflowttp) ------------------------------ Openflow protocol [openflow-specification-ref] has separated networking devices data path from the control plane by describing packet processing pipe line (as a sequence of forwarding tables) independent of control protocols. But vendors use completely different forwarding pipelines based on switch ASIC specifications and there is no way standardize the forwarding plane. Table Type Patterns specification [openflow-ttp-specification-ref] enables users to define abstract switch models. TTP is one type of Network Data Models that are used to describe open flow-logical switch. Each TTP includes unique ID, required OF protocol features, Forwarding Table Map, Meter Table, Flow Table along with Flow Types and Group Table with group entries. Controller and switches can use OF-Config protocol to synchronize controller and switch TTP contexts. ONF Forwarding Abstraction Group defined some standard TTPs [openflow-ttp-repository-ref], which can be used for negotiation between controller and switch. Class OpenflowTTP (Capability): PREFIX = NetworkCapabilityGroup.PREFIX + : + NetworkCapabilityGroup.OPENFLOWTTP OFDPA = self.PREFIX + :ofdpa IPv4_ROUTER = self.PREFIX + :ipv4-router REST API impact ============== None. Security impact ============== None. Notifications impact ================= None. Other end user impact =================== None. Performance Impact ================== None. Other deployer impact =================== Deployer need to populate inventory table for some of the new standard resource classes defined in this spec, if these capabilities need to be considered for scheduling a server. Some capabilities shall be discovered during host initialization phase, remaining capabilities need to be configured by the administrator. Developer impact =============== Developers will need to be aware of the new modeling for capabilities and start consuming these standard capabilities in their modules while processing the constraints associated with these capabilities instead of relying on `metadata` and other free-form data modeling. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ========== Primary assignee: Arun Yerra: Arun_Yerra@DELL.com Other contributors: Ramki Krishnan: Ramki_Krishnan@dell.com Joseph Gasparakis: joseph.gasparakis@intel.com Work Items =========== . Add resource class corresponding to each standard hardware capability . Populate inventory table for each resource class during host initialization Dependencies ============ This specification depends on the nova specification [nova-standardize-capabilities-ref] that defines the mechanism to standardize hardware capabilities. Testing ======= Not much more than unit testing needed. Much of this blueprint is about achieving agreement on the various capability groups and codes. Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== [vxlan-ref] Virtual eXtensible Local Area Network (VXLAN): A Framework for Overlaying Virtualized Layer 2 Networks over Layer 3 Networks, https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7348.txt [gre-ref] Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE), https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2784.txt [nvgre-ref] NVGRE: Network Virtualization Using Generic Routing Encapsulation, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7637/ [mpls-ref] Multi-protocol Label Switching Architecture , https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3031 [geneve-ref] Geneve: Generic Network Virtualization Encapsulation, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-nvo3-geneve/ [vxlangpe-ref] Generic Protocol Extension for VXLAN, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-nvo3-vxlan-gpe/ [span-rspan-ref] Configuring SPAN and RSPAN, http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst2960/software/release/12-2_55_se/configuration/guide/scg_2960/swspan.html [mirroring-ovs-ref] Port mirroring with OpenvSwitch, http://blog.manula.org/2014/02/port-mirroring-with-openvswitch.html [crypto-accln-ref1] Intel QuickAssist Technology API Programmers Guide, https://01.org/sites/default/files/page/330684-001us_api_pg.pdf [crypto-accln-ref2] Agilio CX Intelligent Server Adapters, https://www.netronome.com/products/intelligent-server-adapters/agilio-cx/ [compression-accln-ref] Intel QuickAssist Technology API Programmers Guide, https://01.org/sites/default/files/page/330684-001us_api_pg.pdf [large-send-ref] TCP Segmentation or Large Send Offload, http://kb.pert.geant.net/PERTKB/LargeSendOffloadLSO [large-recv-ref] Large Receive Offload, https://www.usenix.org/legacy/event/usenix08/tech/full_papers/menon/menon_html/paper.html [recv-side-scaling-ref] Receive Side Scaling for TCP, http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/support/network-and-i-o/ethernet-products/000006703.html [stateless-tunnel-offload-ref] Optimizing the Virtual Network with VXLAN Overlay Offloading, https://software.intel.com/en-us/blogs/2015/01/29/optimizing-the-virtual-networks-with-vxlan-overlay-offloading [multiqueue-ref] Multiqueue, commit_message:
Standardize capabilities using Enums

We propose to standardize the representation of capabilities (system,
host, hypervisor, device, etc) into a set of
nova.objects.fields.Enum-based classes that codify various currently
free-form strings into a structured set of standardized capability
descriptors.

Change-Id: Icb1daaedb9d576594e4bb455dda3443fedd9004e
blueprint: standardize-capabilities
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/62/309762/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Standardize Capabilities ======================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/standardize-capabilities We propose to standardize the representation of capabilities (system, host, hypervisor, device, etc) into a set of nova.objects.fields.Enum-based classes that codify various currently free-form strings into a structured set of standardized capability descriptors. Problem description =================== Nova has no way of exposing capabilities of the deployment (the system itself), the host machines inside it, the hypervisors that run workloads, or the devices that can be consumed by workloads. That Nova does not expose this information is actually a Good Thing at the moment, because we have little to no consistency in how we internally define capabilities. Some capabilities are locked up in hard-coded constants in Python modules. Other capabilities are encoded in a nova.conf configuration option. Yet others are free-form key/value strings attached to flavors. And still others are queried from the underlying hardware and used as-is without any sort of canonicalization or normalization applied. If we would like to expose host, system, hypervisor or device capabilities, we first need to standardize the way that we define and represent these things. Use Cases --------- As an end user of an OpenStack cloud, I wish to be able to deploy across multiple cloud providers. I want to be able to query for the capabilities that the cloud provider exposes -- from a system, host, hypervisor, and device perspective -- and I need this capability information to be the same across clouds in order to be assured that any requirements my workloads have with regards to things like host or device capabilities can be met consistently. Proposed change =============== We propose to create a set of `nova.objects.fields.Enum` classes for representing the capabilities of various components in the system. Followup blueprints will tackle the migration of existing capabilities to a standardized database schema model and tackle the creation of REST APIs that expose various capabilities at the different levels of the system. But first, what is a capability exactly? It's important to be very clear on what a capability is, and critically, what a capability is *not*. A capability is a *singular* piece of information describing some **functionality** or **feature** of an entity that can be provided to a consumer. A capability is *not* a *set* of things describing some functionality (that is a set of capabilities). Capabilities must be described as a single value, not a key/value combination. However, groups of related capabilities should be modeled in the system in order to allow for grouping and filtering operations. Let's see some examples of capabilities. x86 architecture CPU instruction set extensions ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The Intel x86 architecture has a number of CPU instruction set extensions. These extensions have names like `sse`, `mmx`, `avx`, and `avx2`. It is important for clouds to be able to inform users of these CPU instruction set extensions in order for a workload to best take advantage of them. When referring to the **capability** of a host to expose these CPU instruction sets to a guest, we might represent this as a *set* of capabilites, such as: * `hw:x86_cpu_instruction_set_ext:sse` * `hw:x86_cpu_instruction_set_ext:mmx` * `hw:x86_cpu_instruction_set_ext:avx` * `hw:x86_cpu_instruction_set_ext:avx2` It is important to note that the above lists *four capabilities*, not a single capability with four possible values. We could say that the above four capabilities all belong to a capability group called `hw:x86_cpu_instruction_set` and that all capabilities in that group belong to a wider group called `hw`. "hypervisor" capabilities ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ I put "hypervisor" in quotes above because libvirt, of course, is not a hypervisor itself, but rather an abstraction layer on top of hypervisors. libvirt offers a number of capabilities, many of which are listed as constants defining the version of libvirt where a feature first appeared in the `nova.virt.libvirt.driver` module. Some of these capabilities include huge page support, setting an admin password, booting from UEFI, etc. XenAPI, Hyper-V, and vCenter hypervisor drivers also need to expose support for various features. We might express these kinds of capabilities like this: * `virt:libvirt:set_admin_pass` * `virt:libvirt:huge_pages` * `virt:libvirt:uefi_boot` * `virt:hyperv:secure_boot` Bad examples of capabilities ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ As mentioned before, capabilities are singular in nature, meaning the value of the capability should not be a set or range of things, nor should the value be interpreted. Here are some examples of what capabilities should **not** look like: * `virt:hyperv_version:2012r2` The problem with the above is that the value does not describe a **feature** of an entity. Instead, it describes some metadata about the entity. A **feature** is something that the entity can perform or provide for a consumer. A version is not something that an entity can provide or perform for a consumer. of values that exist for Hyper-V versions. * `hw:x86_cpu_instruction_set:avx,avx2` The problem with the above is that two values are combined into a single capability. * `virt:libvirt_version:>=1.2.1` The value above implies a range (greater than or equal to libvirt version 1.2.1). This isn't a capability. Rather, the above is representing more of a constraint or preference. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- A series of `Enum` field classes will be added that provide a standardized taxonomy for capabilities:: class CapabilityGroup(Enum): """Groups of capabilities.""" SYSTEM = 'sys' HARDWARE = 'hw' HYPERVISOR = 'virt' class Capability(Enum): pass class X86CPUInstructionSetExtension(Capability): """Intel x86 instruction set extensions""" PREFIX = CapabilityGroup.HARDWARE + ':x86_cpu_instruction_set_ext:' SSE = PREFIX + 'sse' MMX = PREFIX + 'mmx' AVX = PREFIX + 'avx' AVX2 = PREFIX + 'avx2' ALL = ( SSE, MMX, AVX, AVX2, ) class LibvirtFeature(Capability): """Features of the libvirt hypervisor manager.""" PREFIX = CapabilityGroup.HYPERVISOR + ':libvirt:' SET_ADMIN_PASS = PREFIX + 'set_admin_pass' UEFI_BOOT = PREFIX + 'uefi_boot' HUGE_PAGES = PREFIX + 'huge_pages' ALL = ( SET_ADMIN_PASS, UEFI_BOOT, HUGE_PAGES, ) The above are merely examples. Not complete by any means, but meant to illustrate how to codify the various capabilities within Nova. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- Developers will need to be aware of the new modeling for capabilities so that they can utilize the new Enum classes instead of expanding the scope of things like `system_metadata`, nova.conf options and other free-form data modeling. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jaypipes Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- 1. Reach agreement on top-level capability groups 2. Create Enum classes representing capability groups and add a set of capability enums for some hardware and hypervisor features. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Not much more than unit testing needed. Much of this blueprint is about achieving agreement on the various capability groups and codes. Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== None. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Add tooz service group driver

This specification proposes adding a new service group driver based that
makes use of tooz (a new oslo library).
It also talks about deprecating the existing Zookeeper and Memcache
service group drivers, and a migration strategy to the new tooz driver.

Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Garbutt <john.garbutt@rackspace.com>

Previously-approved: liberty
Implements: blueprint tooz-for-service-groups
Depends On: I3cae9495373c4334fedb18b64d907f3a6ac5ab92

Change-Id: Ibf70c2dbe308fc8e4dd277d8c75c4445b3dfce90
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/22/222422/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================= Replace Zookeeper, Memcache servicegroup driver with Tooz drivers ================================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/tooz-for-service-groups Nova's zookeeper and memcache service group drivers have fallen into disrepair. `tooz`_ (a new oslo library that has been under development for around a year) is able to provide the grouping concepts in a way that means nova would no longer need to maintain the zookeeper and memcache service group drivers. Problem description =================== Nova currently has to maintain, test and support db, memcache, zookeeper drivers. The db driver is currently the only widely deployed driver. The memcache and zookeepr drivers have since fallen into disrepair. For example, the Zookeeper driver uses evzookeeper which is no longer actively maintained and doesn't work with eventlet >= 0.17.1. If Nova adds a `tooz`_ service group driver, it means Nova can deprecate the existing zookeeper and memcache drivers, and eventually no longer have to maintain that code. Longer term, its hoped users will be able to migrate away from the db driver to the more promising systems supported by `tooz`_, but this effort it outside the scope of this specification. Use Cases ---------- * In scope: Migrate existing memcache and zookeeper driver users to the new tooz service group driver * Out of scope: Existing db driver users migrate to the tooz driver Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Before this effort can start, we need to fix the service group API abstraction: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/servicegroup-api-control-plane The above effort is likely to extend the amount of the data that needs to be stored by tooz, such as if the node is enabled or disabled. At the same time, this will make clear many of the current limitations of the existing non-DB service group drivers that need to be avoided in the tooz driver. A ToozServiceGroupDriver will be added that implements the existing ServiceGroupDriver interface. Although the above work may adjust the interface slightly. It will simply wrap calls into the `tooz`_ library, and raise Nova specific exceptions for errors that are hit. Alternatives ------------ We could do nothing, but that is unlikely to get the broken drivers fixed, leading to lots of confusion for users, and painful upgrades. We could just drop support for memcache and zookeeper service group drivers all together, but there appears to be a community that wants to support them via `tooz`_ and it would be good to support that community. We could attempt a live-upgrade from Nova's memcache and zookeeper drivers to the new `tooz`_ driver, but given those drivers appear to be currently broken, that seems like wasted effort. User feedback during the deprecation cycle can be used to decide if this is needed before we remove the drivers from the Nova code base. Data model impact ----------------- The DB service group driver will be unaffected by this change. The memcache and zookeeper drivers do not store information in those system in the same way that `tooz`_ stores information. But Nova is just a user of the `tooz`_ library, so we can skip over the details of that change here. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None expected, there will still need to be periodic heartbeats into memcache to ensure the memcache key is not expired, zookeeper clients (even using `kazoo`_ also need to periodically check-in with zookeeper) so nothing should be drastically different in this arena. Other deployer impact --------------------- There will be a new configuration value for the `tooz` driver, using a URL. A few examples of this URL format:: servicegroup_tooz_url = "kazoo://127.0.0.1:2181?timeout=5" servicegroup_tooz_url = "memcached://localhost:11211?timeout=5" servicegroup_tooz_url = "redis://localhost:6379?timeout=5" Given the current state of Nova's memcache and zookeeper drivers, we are adopting a very simple transition approach. It will be something like: * Upgrade to liberty, using existing service group driver * Restart nova-compute first. * Update configuration to point at new service group driver * Restart nova-api after updating configuration. We will look for feedback from users on this approach during the deprecation window for the memcache and zookeeper drivers, to assess if the simpler approach will be sufficient. Developer impact ---------------- Nova developers may have to interact more with the oslo community (and the tooz subcommunity) when learning, understanding, and integrating with tooz. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: vilobhmm Work Items ---------- * Implement the new tooz servicegroup driver. * Document the migration from existing drivers to the tooz driver, including the implementation of any required data migration. * Add deprecation warnings for memcache and zookeeper drivers. * Complete testing work detailed below. Dependencies ============ This spec adds a dependency on tooz This work also depends on the work to tidy up the service group API: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/servicegroup-api-control-plane Testing ======= * Work with infra to ensure one of the gate jobs starts using the tooz driver Documentation Impact ==================== * Describe the new tooz driver and its configuration options * Describe how to migrate from memcacahe or zookeeper to `tooz` * Communicate the deprecation of the memcache and zookeeper drivers References ========== Tooz adoption by oslo: - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/122439/ Tooz rtd: - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tooz/ Others: - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/190322/ - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Oslo/blueprints/service-sync - http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ceilometer-specs/specs/juno/cent\ ral-agent-partitioning.html - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2015-Marc\ h/006674.html - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-April/062737.html .. _tooz: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tooz .. _kazoo: http://kazoo.readthedocs.org/

commit_message:
PCI passthrough device role tagging

Extend role tagging to support PCI passthrough devices. This includes
some clarifications on the existing spec definition.

Change-Id: I92e0410a761dfca0b8e7216c9eddeaf86d1ec592
Blueprint: virt-device-role-tagging
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/28/307028/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== PCI passthrough device role tagging =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/pci-passthrough-tagging Provide a mechanism for a user to tag a PCI passthrough device that has been shared via a flavor with a specific role. The tag will be matched to the device information and this mapping exposed to the guest OS via the metadata service/cloud-init. Problem description =================== The virt-device-role-tagging spec proposes support for tagging functionality for virtual devices. The spec covers network interface cards (NICs) and disk drives, but there are other types of device that can be provided to a guest and would benefit from tagging functionality. One such device type is PCI devices - GPUs, accelerators etc. - that are shared as "passthrough" devices. Like NICs and disk drives, multiple PCI devices can be provided to a guest, and having the ability to distinguish between these can be beneficial. This is particularly important where many similar devices are shared. Use Cases ---------- The use cases for this feature are similar to those found in the virt-device-role-tagging spec. Namely, the tenant user needs to provide information to the guest instance to identify which device to use for a desired guest application role. For example, FPGA devices provide programmable hardware that can be utilsed for many workloads. Loading the algorithm to execute (e.g. the bitstream) into the FPGA is a slow process that should be avoided where possible. By tagging FPGA devices that are passed through as PCI device, the guest can uniquely identify the role of each FPGA device and only load a new bitstream if the role has changed. In a similar manner, PCIe disks (based on NVMe) can be used to provide fast, local, ephemeral storage for instances. However, as these are not tracked as volumes via Cinder, it is not possible to use the semantics proposed in the original spec. The tenant user can still tag these devices to gain similar advantages, e.g. a fast NVMe-based SSD could be shared to use as a highspeed local cache for a DB instance whose persistent datastore is provided by a Cinder volume. The tenant needs to be able to provide this identification information to the guest OS, without knowing about how the particular hypervisor will configure the virtual hardware. Proposed change =============== The proposal is to extend the PCI passthrough extra spec definition, so that it is possible to pass an opaque string "tag". This tag will be used to prepare a metadata file, which will be used by the same services specified in the virt-device-role-tagging spec. It is not possible to extend tagging support to passthrough devices in the exact same manner as tagging for NICs and disk driver. While these two items are "first-class citizen" on the Nova command line and associated with given instances, PCI passthrough devices are specified as part of flavor and are therefore associated with given flavors. As a result, it is the parsing of the flavor extra spec that will change. For example, consider that the user ran :: nova flavor-key m1.large set "pci_passthrough:alias"="a1:2:mygpu" nova boot \ --image mywebappimage \ --flavor m1.large \ mygpuapp Then Nova could then auto-generate a metadata file that contained the following, based on information reported by the Nova libvirt driver for the guest instance: :: { "devices": [ { "type": "pci", "bus": "pci", "address": "0000:00:02.0", "tags": ["mygpu"] }, ] } This builds upon the definition provided in the original spec by providing an additional "type": 'pci'. All other fields remain the same, with similar constraints. Alternatives ------------ There are two alternatives. The first is to do nothing: users can continue to hard code PCI IDs in their applications, and distinguishing between two devices with similar IDs will remain an error prone process. The other option is to promote PCI passthrough devices to "first-class citizens" of the Nova command line and associate devices with instances at boot time. This would allow us to use similar tagging semantics to those used for NICs and disk drives :: nova boot \ --image mywebappimage \ --flavor m1.large \ --passthrough name=a1,alias=2,tag=mygpu mygpuapp This is a much larger body of work, however, and would require another spec. Data model impact ----------------- The PCIDevice object (and associated table) will gain a freeform string attribute, named "tag". REST API impact --------------- The format of the ``pci_passthrough:alias`` extra spec option will be extended to allow for an additional, optional, freeform string parameter :: nova flavor-key m1.large set "pci_passthrough:alias"="a1:2:mygpu" As extra specs are not validated by the client, this would require no changes for the clients and no API microversion. Security impact --------------- None, this is merely providing some user metadata to the guest OS. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- It will be possible to specify additional detail in ``pci_passthrough:alias`` extra spec key. The metadata service and cloud-init will need to recognise the new device "type". Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sfinucan Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Define new attribute for ``PCIDevice`` object * Modify the parsing code for the ``pci_passthrough:alias`` extra spec parameter to handle tags * Modify the metadata file generator to be able to include ``PCI`` type devices Dependencies ============ The virt-device-role-tagging spec must be implemented first. Testing ======= The Intel PCI CI tests will be extended to cover this new format. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation for the ``pci_passthrough:alias`` extra spec parameter will need to be updated to reflect the support for tags. References ========== * * `resource-classes` blueprint: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova-specs/tree/specs/newton/approved/virt-device-role-tagging.rst History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced
